headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the MasterCard Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Heather, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.  I will now turn the call o
componenttext: Welcome to the MasterCard Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Heather, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.  I will now turn the call over to Ms. Barbara Gasper, Head of Investor Relations. Ms. Gasper, you may begin.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for a discussion about our fourth quarter and full year 2014 financial results. With me on the call today are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-
componenttext:
Thank you, Heather, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for a discussion about our fourth quarter and full year 2014 financial results. With me on the call today are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-Mejean, our Chief Financial Officer. Following comments from Ajay and Martina, the operator will announce your opportunity to get into the queue for the Q&A session. Up until then, no one is actually registered to ask a question. [Operator Instructions] 
This morning's earnings release and the slide deck that will be referenced on this call can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website at mastercard.com. We've added a new table in the slide appendix to the deck that breaks out the impact of various items to our financial results as an easy reference for those of you who track that detail. These documents have also been attached to an 8-K that we filed with the SEC earlier this morning. A replay of this call will be posted on our website for 1 week through February 6.
Finally, as set forth in more detail in today's earnings release, I need to remind everyone that today's call may include some forward-looking statements about MasterCard's future performance. Actual performance could differ materially from what is suggested by our comments today. Information about the factors that could affect future performance are summarized at the end of our press release as well as contained in our recent SEC filings.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Ajay.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. I'm very pleased that we were able to deliver strong results of both our fourth quarter and the full year performance despite what everybody knows as a mixed economic environment. In the fourth quarter, after a
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. I'm very pleased that we were able to deliver strong results of both our fourth quarter and the full year performance despite what everybody knows as a mixed economic environment. In the fourth quarter, after adjusting for currency, we had net revenue growth of 17% and EPS growth of 25%, driven by solid underlying metrics. For the full year, we saw net revenue growth of 14% and EPS growth of 19%. Both EPS growth figures exclude the impact of last year's special item for the charge related to the U.S. merchant litigation.
So in total, we have a good year where we were able to continue to meaningfully invest in growth initiatives that I think will position us very well for the future. And those initiatives and triggered actions resulting in a restructuring charge in this past year's fourth quarter, which Martina is going to go through in some detail later.
So moving on to look at the some of the current underlying global economic trends. Let's start with the United States, which is in relatively decent shape. Our SpendingPulse data showed U.S. retail sales growth, x auto, was 2.9% in the fourth quarter, but that's down from the third quarter growth of 4.2%. And most of that deceleration is due to lower gas prices. By excluding auto and gas, retail sales growth of [ph] 4.1% for the fourth quarter versus 4.80% for the third quarter, showing just a modest deceleration in spending.
And even though 4% growth is nothing to [indiscernible] at, we haven't yet seen the extra savings from lowered gas prices translate into additional discretionary consumer spending. So while overall retail spending grew softer in the quarter, underlying economic indicators that remain positive with unemployment levels and consumer sentiment both showing some improvement. 
Looking at our own U.S. business, as we said for the past couple of quarters, the share deconversion is having an impact on our U.S. GDV growth rate, but if you take out, the underlying growth remains roughly the same over the course of 2014.
Outside of the U.S., Europe's recovery slowed somewhat in the fourth quarter. It still remains challenged and across the region, consumer confidence and economic sentiment decelerated slightly. And while unemployment levels are high, the event [indiscernible] was the prior quarter. But there were a few bright spots in the U.K. experienced good momentum in the quarter. SpendingPulse data for the U.K. is showing fourth quarter retail sales growth of 3.6%, up from 2.9% in the third quarter. 
Even in Spain, preliminary indicators are showing some early signs of recovery. MasterCard's total European volume growth for the fourth quarter was in the midteens and processed transaction growth in the lower 20s, both of which increased from the last quarter due in part to a number of our recent wins across several European markets.
Latin America. Number of indicators there that highlighted the sluggish economic performance across the region. And our fourth quarter SpendingPulse data for Brazil showed retail sales growth of just 0.9%, down from the 2.4% growth that Brazil saw in the third quarter. For the entire region, annual GDP growth is now expected to be around 1%, down slightly from earlier projections of 1.3%.
Mexico, however, is an exception. It continues to benefit from improving [indiscernible] the U.S. and actually undergoing a slow recovery. Our business in the region remains solid. Our fourth quarter GDV and processed transaction growth is in the midteens, about the same as the last quarter.
Across Asia Pacific. Overall business sentiment actually improved in the fourth quarter. Optimism from Indian companies following the recent elections has driven some of that, but is temporary by lingering concerns over the slowing economic growth in China. Consumer confidence across the region holding steady. Our business in the region continues to do well. GDV growth in the midteens. Process transactions growth in the mid-20s, about the same as the last quarter.
So overall, the economic environment hasn't changed much from last quarter. The U.S. tends to be in the better shape. Challenges remaining for continental Europe, for Brazil, parts of Asia. But despite all of this, you can see the strong fundamentals that our business has not changed.
So before we go to our business highlights, there's been some recent news about European regulatory matters and Russia, so let me touch on those a little bit first. And let me start with the proposed European legislation related to card payments.
The European Parliament, the Council of Ministers and the Commission have reached an agreement in December and we are awaiting for the formal adoption and publication of the final text. As expected, [indiscernible] that are now being established for consumer credit and consumer debit cards. Commercial cards are excluded. The regulation provides for the level playing field by imposing interchange caps on 3-party [ph] networks when they operate similarly to a 4-party network. There are some possible exceptions to this but overall, we are pleased with outcome in this part is an important one for us.
Also, a network will no longer be allowed to charge a co-value fee if it does not process the transaction. And finally, the regulation requires the functional rather than legal separation of team and processing functions and outcome [indiscernible] was to became clear that some form of separation will be required. We are working to bring this separation, the functional separation into our operations.
The next form of text is for the language of the agreement to be endorsed by parliament and by the member states. Our best estimates is [indiscernible] in the first half of 2015. Interchange caps have become effective 6 months after that. All of parts of legislation will apply to us starting 12 months after the endorsement. So that's probably sometime in 2016.
So a little bit about Russia. We've been working through the challenges of connecting to [indiscernible], which is the domestic processing switch of the Russian Central Bank in order to meet their late March 31 deadline. I'm going forward by the way. Nothing has changed in terms of being able to issue MasterCard-branded cards for use in the Russian market in terms of the financial impact to our business. Our best estimate is still something less than $50 million on an annualized basis. It will now hit our G&A line. The expense line has a data processing expense rather than the revenue line as previously shared. 
So moving on to some of our recent business activity. We've expanded the relationships, the couple of our large global customers and that's great news. We renewed our multiyear global partnership with Bank of America that will expand share opportunity for us both domestically and outside of the U.S. and primarily on commercial side.
We recently won new business with HSBC, which should all converting to the remainder of our U.S. consumer credit portfolio to MasterCard in the first half of this year.
In the Middle East and Africa, we find a number of new business agreements in the quarter. That should help us increase our credit, debit, commercial and prepaid businesses in countries such as Nigeria, Tanzania, Rowanda, Jordan, Kuwait and the UAE over the course of 2015. And we will build with a strong momentum that we've developed in the region. Over the last 2 years, we signed close to 100 new business agreements that now will [indiscernible] footprint in 30 of Africa's 35 markets.
We feel strongly about activities that take our services to people who were previously excluded from access to the financial system. In Africa, close to 95% of the region's transaction are [indiscernible] in cash. 80% of adults don't have access to a bank account. And working around on their whole aspect and reflecting our commitment towards going in Africa, we've also launched a number of financial inclusion in this [indiscernible]. 
Today, I will pick on 2 of those. First, last week, we announced the start of a collaboration with the African Development Bank to broaden access to financial services. We're going to do that in partnership with local governments in Africa and private sector companies. We have the experties to design and to scale financial solutions. And the African Development Bank is a major source of funding for the economic development of its if 34 [ph] member countries.
So we believe together we can help drive financial execution and economic development across Africa over the next 2 years.
Secondly, last September, in partnership with the [indiscernible] Foundation, we announced that we will be opening a MasterCard lab for financial inclusion in Kenya. This is our seventh global innovation, but it's the first that we have in Africa. It's also the first to receive outside funding.
The last will be dedicated specifically to creating and incubating programs that are targeted to more than 100 million people in this part of the world who are financially included or underserved.
Our efforts on innovation, by the way, are not limited to 1 region like [indiscernible] Africa but only to labs. We're also opening up our technology to external developers. Something we've been trying to do for a while now. The most recent example is the 10-city [indiscernible] competition that starts next month in Sydney in Australia and go on Hong Kong, Singapore, Israel, Brazil, Canada, the U.K. and the United States. In this competition, which is already being planned to some of most of these -- beyond these will bring together developers and entrepreneurs using MasterCard APIs to create a new generation of commerce applications that leverages our platforms, our product capabilities such as the information for the business of Mastercards and our prepared, our loyalty and our product solutions.
In the meanwhile, we're continuing the global expansion of MasterPass. Since it's introduction in the spring of 2013, we now have the platform launched in 16 countries. And just recently, signed on a number of new merchants, Neimann Marcus, Office Depot, Blue Nile, Broadway.com, just some new names in the merchant list. We're also creating some new and [indiscernible] 20 [ph] partnerships. One example is the in France. Caliph was essentially followed by BNP Paribas [indiscernible] and Societe Generale, who by the way, mainly customers of 1 of our key competitors. And has chosen to partner with MasterPass because of what we believe is our global reach in handling all of that cross-border e-commerce transactions as well as some other domestic transactions, too.
With this partnership, up to 40 million people will have access to MasterPass acceptance with a pay linked to a card from their bank.
And so before I turn it over to Martina, I will quickly update you on 2 recent acquisitions. In December, we acquired the payment gateway services business of Transaction Network Services, TNS. And that deal gives us the ability to expand our payment gateway to the U.S. and Mexico and to position ourselves more competitively around the rest of the world where, as you know, we deal with cash and our original mixed platform we only have a presence. 
And so for example, in Asia Pacific and the Middle East/africa, we will add new capabilities: Tokenization, fraud management and we'll also be able to leverage where I think our highly skilled product and software teams that have now recently joined the company with this transaction.
Additionally, we acquired Five One Marketing Limited. That's a marketing, analytics and consulting firm and their plants are basically large retailers across many different consumer sectors. Five One has a proprietary software. They've used that to develop insights from a retailer's own data that can be used for marketing, for merchandising and for operational decisions. If you take that and you combine that kind of in-depth merchant understanding with our existing adviser's capability, that will then allow us to provide greater insight for retailers and the ability to expand our business opportunities with the merchant community.
So with that, Martina, for an update on financial results and operational metrics.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ajay, and good morning, everyone. As Ajay already said, we're very pleased with our 2014 full year performance, which delivered net revenue growth of 14% and EPS growth of 19%. I'll now go to the details of our fourth quarter results.So let me b
componenttext:
Thanks, Ajay, and good morning, everyone. As Ajay already said, we're very pleased with our 2014 full year performance, which delivered net revenue growth of 14% and EPS growth of 19%. I'll now go to the details of our fourth quarter results.
So let me begin on Page 3 of our slide deck and where you see that the difference between as reported and FX adjusted of growth rate for this quarter is more significant than it has been in recent past. This is primarily due to the hedged [indiscernible] from the euro-U.S. dollar exchange rates, especially with what we saw in the FX markets during the last 45 days of the quarter and this continuation into this quarter.
These figures also exclude the impact of the special item related to the U.S. merchant litigation taken in the fourth quarter of 2013.
I'd like to highlight 3 things right on the slide and then dive into the details of the major P&L line items in subsequent slides. So first, EPS growth was 25% after adjusting for currency and share repurchases contributed $0.03 per share.
During the fourth quarter, we have purchased 2.1 million shares at a cost of approximately $155 million. And through January 23, we will purchase an additional 2.5 million shares at a cost of approximately $213 million and we now have $3.8 billion remaining under the current authorization. We continue to look to repurchase shares on an opportunistic basis.
Second, part of the EPS growth is the result of a very favorable tax rate of 20.3% in the quarter as some initiatives only came together within the last couple of months to better align our tax structure to our European business footprint between Belgium and the U.K. We took some of that benefit to reinvest that into the business, which I discussed on the operating expense slide. And third, cash flow from operations were $725 million. We ended the quarter with cash, cash equivalent and other liquid investments of about $6.4 billion.
So let's turn to Page 4, where you can see the operational metrics for the fourth quarter. Our worldwide growth star volume, or GDV, was up 13% on a local currency basis, up slightly from last quarter. Overall, our used GDV grew 8%, similar to last quarter. Credit growth was 7% and debit growth was 8%. Both the same as last quarter.
Outside of the U.S., volume growth was 13% [ph] on a local-currency basis and primarily driven by Europe.
Cross-border volume grew 19% on a local currency basis, higher than the 15% we saw in the third quarter, primarily driven by Europe. Growth in Europe was in the low 20s. Key contributors to this growth included the U.K., Italy, Germany and Sweden. All regions, except the U.S., saw an increase in cross-border volume growth in the fourth quarter.
Let me turn to Page 5. And here, you can see process transactions grew 11% globally to $11.6 billion. We continued to see double-digit growth in most regions. Growth increase from the 10% we saw in the third quarter primarily due to Europe, driven by Russia, Sweden, Poland and the Netherlands. Globally, the number of calls grew 9% with 2.1 billion MasterCard and Maestro-branded cards.
So let's turn to Page 6 for highlights on a few of our revenue line items. Overall net revenue growth was 14% as reported or 17% FX suggested due to currency headwinds, primarily from the euro exchange rate. Additionally, the impact of local currency exchanges through the [indiscernible] currency billing rate was a little more than 1 ppt. In total, acquisitions contributed 3 ppt to our net revenue growth. So after excluding the impact of both local exceptional currencies as well as the impact of acquisitions, we saw a very strong underlying growth of 15%.
Looking at the individual revenue line items on an FX adjusted basis. Domestic assessments grew 7% while worldwide GDV grew 13%. This 6 ppt gap [ph] is primarily due to the impact of local currency and lower-than-average revenue yields in some markets outside of the U.S. similar to prior quarters.
Cross-border volume fees grew 8% while cross-border volume grew 19%. Of the 11 ppt gap [ph], about 7 ppt is due to the impact of local currency. The remaining portion of this difference is mainly due to the higher mix of intra-European activity.
Transaction processing fees grew 13%, primarily driven by the 11% growth in processed transactions. This line item also benefited from additional revenues not driven by transaction count and some pricing partially offset by mix.
Other revenues grew 28%, driven largely by contributions from our Pinpoint acquisition as well as our Advisors business.
Moving on to Page 7. You can see the total operating expenses were up 26% in the quarter or 29% on an FX adjusted basis. Of this close, 9 ppt was due to expenses related to our acquisitions. The other big driver was the restructuring charge, which contributed 8 ppt to the growth. So let me focus on that a bit more.
So specifically, we took an $87 million restructuring charge to cover a series of actions. First, as you know, we have made a number of acquisitions in the processing space and we're now consolidating all of our processing assets under 1 organization that's driving significant synergies.
Second, we are realigning some roles within the company's business groups and redeploying resources geographically in order to invest in and enhance our capabilities in new product areas and technology such as digital and mobile. Overall, these actions would impact over 500 people but our total headcount will decline by a smaller amount given the reinvestment that I just mentioned.
The remaining OpEx growth of 12% was primarily driven by some opportunistic spent such as adding a spend around our autopay and price initiatives as well as continuing our digital investments such MasterPass and tokenization, similar to prior quarters.
Let me turn to Slide 8. And here, we discussed what we've seen in January through the 21st. Most of our business drivers are similar to what we experienced in the fourth quarter after excluding the impact of lower gas prices, particularly in the U S. So the numbers through January 21 are as follows: Starting with processed volume, we saw global growth of 9%, down 2 ppt from the fourth quarter. In the U.S., our processed volume grew 3%, down 2 ppt from what we saw the last quarter, primarily driven by lower gas prices. Processed volume outside of the U.S. grew 16%, about 1 ppt lower than the fourth quarter with growth of mid- to high-teens in each region. process transaction growth was 11%, similar to what we saw in the fourth quarter with double-digit growth in all regions except the U.S., which grew in the low-single digits.
With respect to cross-border, our volume grew at 19% globally, the same as our fourth quarter growth. We continue to see growth in major European markets including the U.K., Italy and Sweden.
Looking ahead, let me start with some commentary about full year 2015. Given what's happening with currency rates and the impact being seen by U.S. multinationals across a number of industries, I'm going to start with that, especially since it was back in 2012, the MasterCard last faced such a big impact from FX. Remember that currency impact does it 2 ways. So first, we have the impact of local currency rates or [indiscernible] transaction currencies. And then with the FX exposure that [indiscernible] hedged by normally on a rolling 12 months basis that typically, as you know, we hedged about 50% to 75% of our total net exposure for about 30 currency pairs. And given that many currencies have depreciated against the U.S. dollar and the euro, new hedge contracts will come on at lower rates over the year. Thus, we continue to expect some net headwind throughout the year both to revenue and the bottom line. 
Based on currency rates -- based on the current rate, this is likely to be around 2 ppt, in the 2 ppt range and this is already included in our FX adjusted guidance.
Second, we have the impact of the translation of our major functional currencies, which are particularly euro and the Brazilian real into U.S. dollars to consolidate our financials. But we do not hedge those exposures. When we talk about FX adjusted growth rates, we are only adjusting for the impact of these 2 functional exchange rates. As the rates to our functional currencies remain similar to where they are today, so that's the euro trading at the 1 13 level and the Brazilian real at the 2 58 level for the rest of the year, the net impact of the euro and the real would be a 4 to 6 ppt [indiscernible] and has actually driven mostly from the euro to our as reported results for the full year. Depending on which line item we're talking about. Revenue, net income or EPS and I will get into that a little bit more.
With that backdrop, now let me get into some of the P&L line items. We expect high single digit net revenue growth for 2015 on an FX adjusted basis. And that will be before and after a roughly 2 ppt contribution from last year's M&A transactions. Our underlying business remained strong and we are seeing traction from many of our recent portfolio wins and new product initiative. However, this year's FX adjusted revenue growth will be impacted by some items specific to 2015. And that's including the remaining case portfolio attrition, largely impacting the first half of the year, as well as the local currency headwinds I just talked about.
Also included are a couple of expected significant contract renewals, some of which will likely have more front-loaded rebates and incentives than our typical agreements. But these renewals provide the foundation for future growth.
On an as reported basis, the net revenue growth rate will likely be in the mid-single-digit range sa a result of strong FX headwinds, primarily from the euro functional translation. Based on current FX rates, this will be about a 4 ppt to 5 ppt impacts.
Overall, we project the growth rate for total operating expense for full year 2015 to be in the high-single digits on an FX adjusted basis. This growth is predominantly due to a roughly 6 [ph] ppt impact from our previously announced acquisitions, with more of that impact occurring in the first half of the year. The as reported growth will likely be in the mid-single-digit range after considering a roughly 10 to 3 ppt range impact mostly again from the euro translation.
Let me give you an update on potential dilution from last year's acquisitions. Now that we've found a few more deals like TNS and Five beyond that Ajay just mentioned, we now expect total EPS dilution to be about $0.08 to $0.10 for the full year 2015 and a little less than half of the expected dilution is actually due to the amortization of acquired intangibles. You should now assume a full year 2015 tax rate of about 28%, due to the continued balance rate we expect from the cash initiatives I discuss earlier. So this is a sustainable tax benefit for future years.
Now then on the details that I just went through, let me step back and summarize for you. We expect solid fundamentals to drive our business in 2015 despite the mixed economic environment and significant headwinds from FX and gas prices. We continue to sign customer contracts and invest in the right strategic areas while managing our expenses prudently.
So finally, let me move onto our long-term performance objective for the 2013 to 2015 period.
Given our expectations for 2015 revenue growth, we now believe that we would deliver at the low-end of our 11% to 14% net revenue CAGR. We continue to expect at least 20% EPS CAGR for the 3-year period, due to continued expense management as well as benefits from our lower tax rate and share repurchases. We remain committed to our annual operating margin target of at least 50%. Remember, these objectives are at constant currency basis and exclude our 2014 M&A activities as well as any new ones that may occur this year.
As a reference point for your modeling, when looking at our performance on 2 -- from a 2-year CAGR perspective, so that's for 2013 and 2014, on a constant currency basis, we have delivered a net revenue CAGR of 12.5% and an EPS CAGR of 21.1%, which is based on the 2012 normalized EPS of $2.14 per share that we provided to you earlier.
Now many of you have asked when we will be rolling our performance objectives forward. As you can see, the underlying drivers of our business are in good shape and we are expanding our reach in areas that we're strategically targeting such as processing, royalty, information services and all things digital. The overall growth prospects for the payments industry have not changed. And for now we have given you some clarity around 2015 as this is the last year of our current 2013 to '15 performance period. Once we have worked to the many moving parts, including the impact of those resulting from the final European payment regulation and the new payment environment in Russia both from a revenue and an expense perspective, we will provide you with our new long-term objective before the end of this year. 
So let me turn the call back to Barbara to begin the Q&A session. Barbara?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] translate, Sanjay. As you know, we are very much committed to the aligning our business operations to our tax infrastructure. And over the last couple of years, we've been able to work out the tax rates quite considerably. So in fact, in 2
componenttext: [indiscernible] translate, Sanjay. As you know, we are very much committed to the aligning our business operations to our tax infrastructure. And over the last couple of years, we've been able to work out the tax rates quite considerably. So in fact, in 2014, we're ending up at 28.8%, but planning that, that will go down to 28% in 2015 and over a lot of period point of time, we believe we will have even more work that we can do in order to lower the tax rate.

So just curious if there are any unusual items within that. And then can you give us some -- Martina, some context on where rebates could trend this year? Sounds like this -- like you just said, there'll be some renewals and wins.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, in our prior year quarter in 2013 w,e actually had some relatively large contracts coming to fruition, but on a new and from a renewal point of view. So there's just the year-over-year cadence. There's nothing unusual that's just goi
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, in our prior year quarter in 2013 w,e actually had some relatively large contracts coming to fruition, but on a new and from a renewal point of view. So there's just the year-over-year cadence. There's nothing unusual that's just going on in the Q4 of 2014. Looking forward, when you talk about 2015, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we have -- we are expecting a number of customer renewals that will have more front-loaded rebates and incentives in to the fun part of the year, not smooth over at the entire years of the contract. And so we will have a more considerable impact on rebates [indiscernible] in 2015 and that is all baked into our net revenue growth that's of the high single digits FX adjusted.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ajay, I wonder just from a high level if you could step back and kind of describe the acquisition strategy just in the context of your long-term growth. It seems like you're perhaps ramping up some of your acquisition activity. And I wonder if there's som
componenttext: Ajay, I wonder just from a high level if you could step back and kind of describe the acquisition strategy just in the context of your long-term growth. It seems like you're perhaps ramping up some of your acquisition activity. And I wonder if there's some specific criteria you evaluate when you look to do a deal? And also just sort of whether or not there's an overall or overarching narrative that we might think about in terms of how MasterCard's augmenting its robust organic revenue growth and position.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've -- this particular year, we've actually ended up doing 6 acquisitions and 1 JV. And we have this DMS, Five One, Pinpoint, ACSC 7 [indiscernible] starting in January through December and then the [indiscernible] JV. But that's -- I wouldn't say
componenttext: Well, we've -- this particular year, we've actually ended up doing 6 acquisitions and 1 JV. And we have this DMS, Five One, Pinpoint, ACSC 7 [indiscernible] starting in January through December and then the [indiscernible] JV. But that's -- I wouldn't say you should take that out as a not. Deals are deals when they happen. You cannot look at 25, 30 deals in a year. And sometimes, in the previous 2 years, 1 or 2 worked out. It so happened that a number of these were in the hope of so to say and they [indiscernible] and different times of the year. So the first thing I'd say is don't take this [indiscernible] how it happened. It's just the way deals work out. Now should people question [indiscernible] doing going forward [indiscernible] worst of big picture here. As a big picture here, as we are trying to expand our presence in the payments value chain, not just from being in the clearing authorization and [indiscernible] business but everything [indiscernible] before doing and after the transaction. How can we expand our presence so we can be still here and we can, therefore, excite the value for the service of the offer and [indiscernible] with some new capabilities and hopefully gives us some space to become bigger leaders or better leaders in key growth areas. So what could those areas be? Data and analytics, which is the information services of ours. So Five One, for example, is right in that space. Processing, which is what they are doing with [indiscernible] and with ECS. And TNS also does fit in there, demand the keyholes businesses but overtime. So a lot of these things that all ignite to processing and why we're doing processing because the idea is to be able to see more of the transactions around the world. Because that allows me to use that knowledge in my data analytics business. So interconnected to that space. And then the third area is safety and security. So DataCash got us some great fraud management solutions. There are similar ones in some of these. The [indiscernible] JV could actually be very useful not just from moving money around the world but also for safety and security. And then loyalty, which is why Pinpoint came into it then. It is through assets some years ago. And so this is all in that daily wake of data and analytics, processing, safety, security and loyalty. And mostly, we transfigured out of this strategic fit how these companies giving us some critical capabilities. We didn't have our own technology, product, distribution, some geographic reach maybe. And do we have the right kind of risk profile and are we getting some talented skills we were not been able to get easily. So [indiscernible], for example, brought us a number of very highly qualified mobile payment technicians, hiring hundreds of them organically would be a very slow build. This give us the ability to get with it much quicker. Kind of a mix of those reasons and that's what they're trying to do.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In addition to the strategic evaluation, we obviously do of financial evaluation and we do a integration possibility evaluation. So on financials, first of all, we differentiate between those acquisitions that Ajay said that are really bringing our s
componenttext: Yes. In addition to the strategic evaluation, we obviously do of financial evaluation and we do a integration possibility evaluation. So on financials, first of all, we differentiate between those acquisitions that Ajay said that are really bringing our skill set that don't necessarily bring us in the immediate term revenue that would be built over time but it brings us skill set. And then we have acquisitions that are more traditional acquisitions like PinPoint or TMS that are bringing us all the revenues. And we do the very traditional cash flow modeling with the right kind of hurdle rates, marries by the type of business, the riskiness of the business, where the business is located. And then beyond that analysis, we obviously also do an analysis on the integration possibility of this particular business with our company so that we can drive some synergies on the bottom line.

And I don't think you should be expecting too big of a difference from an overall AMS spent number for 2015 than what we had in 2014.

componenttext: Yes. Economic environment translates into consumer confidence, translates into spending and that does in fact quickly. And what's also being on here is conversion from cash to electronic and it's kind of a mixed bag of all 3 that come out into the numbers you're seeing. And you can actually make that work faster in all of you if you've got the right marketing and the right approaches. So it's a lodging and tackling that's going on to help us get to where we're getting.

componenttext: I was just curious in terms of what series you might have as to why we haven't seen the pickup in discretionary spending from U.S. consumers given the magnitude of the drop in gas prices. And then separately, can you just clarify your pricing assumptions in the 2015 guide?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Jason, that's actually a very good question. I myself am kind of stumped with what's going on there. I think about the fact that it's [indiscernible] from a [indiscernible] family, the gas price down 12% over the same time the previous year. And that's
componenttext: So Jason, that's actually a very good question. I myself am kind of stumped with what's going on there. I think about the fact that it's [indiscernible] from a [indiscernible] family, the gas price down 12% over the same time the previous year. And that's not a small number here. So we put all that into context, you were part of fill through. But the way I think about it [indiscernible] we talked to so many other fields about this. I just feel that maybe it is -- that it's going to take 3 or 4 months for the U.S. consumer to feel that this is something that's going to be down for a little while. If you have longer-term perspective on the price of gas not going back to $100, but maybe settling at $75, $80, that's a real thinking. I don't think the U.S. consumer knows whether they expect this to be sticking around or not. So I think there's some degree of, let's say, the desire to see that through before they really start spending that kind of money. That kind of where I think this is. So if you were asked by a payment in a guess, I would say you're probably a month or 2 or 3 away if this price stays where it is. From there, I'd say, you know what, I do have [indiscernible] about a month more in my pocket and I could afford to go and buy x. I think that's kind of what I think about. But on pricing, Martina?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the pricing side, just for 2014 actually for the whole year, we had about a 1% price increase. So relatively small, we think with we have out there for 2015, it will be relatively similar.
componenttext: Yes, on the pricing side, just for 2014 actually for the whole year, we had about a 1% price increase. So relatively small, we think with we have out there for 2015, it will be relatively similar.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, yes. You're absolutely right. FX adjusted [indiscernible] condition and best revenue growth for 2015. That includes about 2 ppt of M&A transactions. But by the way, even when you pull these 2 ptt of M&A transactions out, you still get to high-single g
componenttext: So, yes. You're absolutely right. FX adjusted [indiscernible] condition and best revenue growth for 2015. That includes about 2 ppt of M&A transactions. But by the way, even when you pull these 2 ptt of M&A transactions out, you still get to high-single growth of underlying business, so you can probably get a good sense on the numbers on that one. On the expense side, what I said is also on an FX adjusted basis, you have operating expenses high single digits and actually most of that 6 ppt is due to the acquisitions. So the underlying growth of our underlying expenses is relatively small, okay? Now when you put the FX translation into it, you have to deduct about 2 to 3 percentage points so you're getting for the as reported FX growth into the mid-single-digit range.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you're going to benefit -- you're going to benefit from the euro and expenses, just to the headwind on the revenue. That's kind of what's going on. The M&A transactions, what's happening is you typically get the first year or 2. You tend to get the exp
componenttext: So you're going to benefit -- you're going to benefit from the euro and expenses, just to the headwind on the revenue. That's kind of what's going on. The M&A transactions, what's happening is you typically get the first year or 2. You tend to get the expenses that you're going to do to be able to get them up to speed with our systems or with our security or the investment you're putting in to do things with the technology or the geography or the distribution. I think the revenue that comes in a little later or you're getting things like [indiscernible], which are really more billing capacity on mobile and digital and doesn't really give all the revenue in the first year or 2 or 3. That's the mix of things going on inside the company.

componenttext: Ajay, I had a question around tokenization. The time outline for tokenization for online browser-based purchases? I think Visa had mentioned maybe there could be some products over the next few quarters? How will that sort of play out?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the fourth [indiscernible], if you can't bust it up between in-app, contactless and online browser as you pay through it. Contactless is still relatively small in the U.S. Online browsing tends to be the large amount. A number of the merchants and reta
componenttext: So the fourth [indiscernible], if you can't bust it up between in-app, contactless and online browser as you pay through it. Contactless is still relatively small in the U.S. Online browsing tends to be the large amount. A number of the merchants and retailers have been launching their own apps in an effort to get people to come straight to their and then hopefully control more of the transaction as well as the relationship with the consumer when they're inside their app as compared to having the usual way. So it depends who you believe but everybody is making projections based, well, whatever they think about where these 3 will go over the next 2 years. And my sense is you're going to get MSE going decently but internally with. And I believe terminalization will happen with all the EMV and chip migration as well as the fact there are new double that are coming contactless. So you're probably seeing a 2- or 3-year cycle of a fairly dramatic increase in contactless equipped terminals in the United States. That's only happening, by the way, in Australia and Canada, Turkey and some other countries. For the U.S., which is the large one, I think you'll see that. In terms of browsing, browsing tends to do a lot of chunk. And I still believe that online browsing will remain a pretty large number for 2 years to. And I think you'll get a 2 or 3 kinds of efforts there. You'll get a lot of effort made around improving the current [indiscernible]. There'll be a lot of efforts made around improving the use of EVU checkout wallets so there'll be MasterPass or Visa offering or PayPal or other such offerings. And then you'll get all of those getting a degree of capability with tokenization just thinking it's safer and safer over the next few quarters. So we're all working on similar things. And I don't think you should read too much in to it quarter here or a quarter there. These things are slow burns. And you saw Apple Pay talk about their mobile payment growth. But at the end of the day, yes, they've done a great job and it's excited the market but it's still very small percentage of what the total number of transactions are. So I will take orders in that context and not [indiscernible] with more than that. We're very focused on tokenization effect. Just to make sure I don't miss that aspect, it's a very important aspect to where we're going for safety and security. Apple Pay was the first version to come out. We're bringing into MasterPass, just regular MasterPass, over the next few period of time, let me put it that way. So let me give you information that's beyond what is likely. And that will be -- you'll see in a year or 2 time, tokenization will become kind of table stakes in the games on e-commerce. So that's how we're going to go.

componenttext: No. I don't -- the last part of your question is about is there any steering or secular change going on in the behavior around credit and debit? And I'd say there's no evidence of that. But you should know this that the growth rate of debit versus credit, there are changes that are going on between them over time. And there's no doubt that has -- as credit history and credit position are improving, banks are becoming more willing to go out and push credit acquisitions again. And that's what [indiscernible] some change or bigger the time. Some day of behavior between debit and credit but there's no real pushing us steering or anything going on. So as you can see, not in our numbers anyway.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Martina, you talked about how you actively hedged, I believe, you said 50%, 75% of your FX exposure. Can you discuss some of the trade-offs behind why you wouldn't hedge an even greater percentage? Wouldn't foreign contracts be relatively inexpensive? And
componenttext: Martina, you talked about how you actively hedged, I believe, you said 50%, 75% of your FX exposure. Can you discuss some of the trade-offs behind why you wouldn't hedge an even greater percentage? Wouldn't foreign contracts be relatively inexpensive? And then finally, if you can offer any thoughts at a high level on some of the more significant differences between your hedging strategies versus that of your large competitor, which last night discussed how they're layering their hedges on a rolling 12-month basis?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, with the last comment, of course, we listen to each other's comment from time to time. And I would believe that we do a hedging strategy and have a hedging philosophy that is extremely similar. We lay in our [indiscernible] our hedge
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, with the last comment, of course, we listen to each other's comment from time to time. And I would believe that we do a hedging strategy and have a hedging philosophy that is extremely similar. We lay in our [indiscernible] our hedges over a 12 months volume period so we never want, so to speak, make it during any type of period. But we do it for this most significant currency period. So I think you know that we're doing extra business and have it in 50-plus [ph] currencies but we really picked the most significant currency peers in order to do our hedging. In order to do hedging, you have to have really appropriate exposure forecast coming out over the next 12 months rolling period. And that is where you typically take a step back and take a little bit of a more conservative view and don't layer in 100% of the exposure in terms of hedges. You do 30% to 75%. So we don't take a view, but 50% to 75% is not taking a view in terms of hedging a particular currency pair, but it is in terms of making sure that between the old exposure that we know and the hedges that we lay on that we have the right kind of balance. The one other thing that I wanted to let you know is just to make sure we are hedging things on a net basis, which means we take revenues in that particular currencies and we deduct the operating expenses that we spend in that particular currency and then we do another hedge on that and you would not see the gain or the loss of the hedge showing up on the revenue line. Most of that is actually reflected in our G&A line item.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: By the way, this layered hedging is kind of the way that I do sort given in my previous job at banking industry. When you go to companies, that's exactly what you do. You go and you tend to hedge more of the exposure in the immediate quarter out there, a
componenttext: By the way, this layered hedging is kind of the way that I do sort given in my previous job at banking industry. When you go to companies, that's exactly what you do. You go and you tend to hedge more of the exposure in the immediate quarter out there, a little less than the quarter after, a little less than the quarter after and even a little even in the quarter after. So when Martina talked to you about the 50% to 75%, you're probably looking at a higher-level hedge in the immediate quarter because you have most activity of that net exposure between those currency pairs that she just had for 2. You hedge a little less out 4 quarters because you had less activity in those currency pairs that she's referring to. Also remember, the euro and the real are not being discussed in those currency pairs peers. The 2 percentage points headwind that we've already [indiscernible] in our revenue growth as [indiscernible] for next year is from these currency pairs. The euro and the real consumer and beyond that and kind of could be a far more significant one, particularly because the euro, as Martina was pointing out.

componenttext: So that businesses is exciting. We're doing well and it's across the world, by the way. A focus on TME, a focus on [indiscernible], a focus on purchasing, a focus on some B2B payments streams. It's not just our own effort with individual clients like Bank of America and Chase and Citi. talked about our other global clients. But it's also focused on partnerships with companies in the travel space, a partnership of companies in the [indiscernible] management spaces. All of these are giving us opportunities in commercial.

componenttext: Can you just speak a little bit to the new ones that we might expect to see as you get more and more of these mixed shifted e-commerce? Inherently, it seems a little more credit centric. The categories are quite a bit different and maybe a bigger pool from which everyone to draw from. And I just -- what I'm be thinking about this as this mixed shift accelerates. And the other thing if you could just, I guess, explain the $50 million shift in to G&A versus revenue from Russia? How did that come about? And I'll hop off.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me take the Russia question first. So what actually happened is a last leg of the legislation in Russia is that we continue to be a direct partner in to our clients. And then we actually will be freezing [ph] our clients on all products and service
componenttext: So let me take the Russia question first. So what actually happened is a last leg of the legislation in Russia is that we continue to be a direct partner in to our clients. And then we actually will be freezing [ph] our clients on all products and services that our clients need. And as we went some contracts, in particular, all clear and switching to the local processing entity. And therefore, we still got the revenue from our clients, but we have to pay a servicing fee, which will be showing up in the data processing line to the local entity that would switch on to [indiscernible]. Ajay? E-commerce.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will answer that in a way that still I will tell you that what's going on in e-commerce right now is that you've as you grow, there's no doubt that credit has a greater share than debit in e-commerce. Although I've seen it also because the U.S. is a lar
componenttext: I will answer that in a way that still I will tell you that what's going on in e-commerce right now is that you've as you grow, there's no doubt that credit has a greater share than debit in e-commerce. Although I've seen it also because the U.S. is a larger e-commerce market than most other parts of the world. In Europe is not as similar as it is in the U.S. But remember the U.K. and Spain and Portugal are more credit sensitive and northern Europe is more debit sensitive. So a lot of it depends on the originating market from where the transaction is based in the e-commerce system. So what you're seeing right now is also a function of mix. And I wouldn't try and draw more conclusions on that right now.

componenttext: Just now that the European, the agreement seems to be in place between the 3 parties. Just trying to get an idea of you guys are probably looked at for '16, what kind of impact might there be? And then secondly, Martina, just on operating margins for the year, there's a lot of moving pieces. Should we expect fiscal year '15 operating margins to increase? And then what does that all total out to be for EPS growth as reported for fiscal year '15? Just want to make sure I have that right.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: On your fist question, well, the European regulation of the tax is finalized but there's a lot of work that has to be done in order to implement that. So I'm not going to be able to be giving you guidelines for 2016 at this point of time. And that's why y
componenttext: On your fist question, well, the European regulation of the tax is finalized but there's a lot of work that has to be done in order to implement that. So I'm not going to be able to be giving you guidelines for 2016 at this point of time. And that's why you are going to hear only later this year about our long-term performance targets that we are going to be renewing then for a period. Secondly, on the operating margin, of course, when you have higher single digit revenue growth and higher single digit OpEx growth on an FX adjusted basis, you should basically assume that the operating margin, which is terrific, for 2013 will be roughly a similar operating margin in 2015. We're not giving guidance for the bottom line.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me now turn the call over to Ajay Banga for closing remarks. Ajay?
componenttext: Let me now turn the call over to Ajay Banga for closing remarks. Ajay?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you also for those questions. And I'm just going to leave you with the 2 closing thoughts. We ended what I think was a very good year on a strong note. I mean, 17% revenue growth in fourth quarter [indiscernible] '14 with FX not a bad place t
componenttext: Great. Thank you also for those questions. And I'm just going to leave you with the 2 closing thoughts. We ended what I think was a very good year on a strong note. I mean, 17% revenue growth in fourth quarter [indiscernible] '14 with FX not a bad place to be. Volumes, shares, innovation, deals, we've done all that while navigating through what I would say was one of the more complex economic and political years that I've seen over the last decade. And aside from the actual couple of years of the financial crisis, this was done on a more difficult years. For 2015, we see the same underlying trends economically and for our own business. We believe that we will deliver our 3 objectives and that means that net revenue growth this year will be in the high single-digit range at constant currency. So your question will be why is that growth lower than 2014? Because, one, we have those local FX headwinds [indiscernible] discussing in the Q&A and those 30 currency pairs. So that's before the euro and the real translation impact, which, as you know, is larger. But just those local FX headwinds and because we have some very good deals in the pipeline both renewals and wins that probably are going to have an upfront load. But they're good deals, they're good for us. And so if you look at all that at the same time, we plan to keep investing in our business and our capabilities. We know how to dial our expenses up and down. And we are going to keep a very close eye on that, if needed. I just don't want to do that through short-term cycle. Now we took advantage of the tax benefit, but why is that sustainable, as Martina talked about. They come to us in the latter part of the quarter and got finalized and she said, you know what, this is a good time. Apple Pay is out of the market. Price initiatives are out of the market. It's a good season for all of us. Let's take some of those benefits and put it back into the system. Those kinds of provisions are taken every week and every day by us together as a team. So overall, we haven't changed our thinking about our business prospects from what we indicated at our Investor Day a few months ago but other the 2 [indiscernible]. The space is a terrific plays to be. We are very confident in our ability to guide this company to the current mix environment and we're going to keep growing share and we're going to keep driving the conversion of cash to electronic payments around the world. I think we'd expect to continue to deliver strong financial performance in the foreseeable future. So thank you so much for your continued support of our company. Thank you for taking the time to join us today.
