headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the MasterCard First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Keith, and I will be operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Ms. Barbara Gasp
componenttext: Welcome to the MasterCard First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Keith, and I will be operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Ms. Barbara Gasper, Head of Investor Relations. Ms. Gasper, you may begin.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining us for a discussion about our first quarter 2013 financial results. With me on the call this morning are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-Mejean, our Ch
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining us for a discussion about our first quarter 2013 financial results. With me on the call this morning are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-Mejean, our Chief Financial Officer. Following comments from Ajay and Martina, the operator will announce your opportunity to get into the queue for the Q&A session. Up until then, no one is actually registered to ask a question here [Operator Instructions] 
This morning's earnings release and the slide deck that will be referenced on this call can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website, MasterCard.com. These comments have been also attached to an 8-K that we filed with the SEC earlier this morning. A replay of this call will be posted on our website for 1 month. 
Finally, as set forth in more detail in today's earnings release, I need to remind everyone that today's call may include some forward-looking statements about MasterCard's future performance. Actual performance could differ materially from what is suggested by our comments today. Information about the factors that could affect future performance are summarized at the end of our press release, as well as contained in our recent SEC filings. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Ajay.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. In the first quarter, we have reported net revenue growth of 3%, and that's 8% after adjusting for currency. And that, combined with a decrease in operating expense of 1%, or an increase of 3% on an ethics adju
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. In the first quarter, we have reported net revenue growth of 3%, and that's 8% after adjusting for currency. And that, combined with a decrease in operating expense of 1%, or an increase of 3% on an ethics adjusted basis, is what helped us drive EPS growth of 22%, and that number is 29% when adjusted for currency. So as we expected and, I guess, no different from other large global companies, FX is having a noticeable impact on our results and especially the euro and real, both have depreciated about 18% against the U.S. dollar versus this time last year, that is last year's first quarter. 
However, our EPS growth continues to be strong, both on as reported and an ethics adjusted basis. So as usual, let's begin to look at some of the current underlying global economic trends and let's start with the United States. Our spending data, showed that U.S. retail sales growth x auto was 1.1% in the first quarter and that's down from the fourth quarter growth rate of 2.9%, and that deceleration continues basically to be due to lower gas prices. If you were to exclude auto and gas, retail sales growth was 5.1% for the first quarter versus 4.1% for the fourth quarter, and that shows a healthier growth rate. So what I think is happening is that consumer are only using a small portion of that savings from gas to buy new goods and services, rather what they are doing is using those savings from gas to increase their personal savings rate, which looks like it declined to the highest level since December 2012. And they're probably using it to pay down some debt. And therefore, any additional consumer spend has not been enough to make up for the lower gas spending. 
However, underlying economic indicators have remained steady. Unemployment levels are stable, consumer sentiment is tracking upwards. So when you look at our U.S. business, lower gas prices had an impact of about 2 percentage points on our U.S. GDV growth rate, which is slightly greater than the 1 percentage point headwind we saw in the fourth quarter. GDV growth, excluding gas and process transactions, were essentially the same as last quarter. 
In Europe, the environment there are showing signs of improvement. And across the region consumer confidence, economic confidence, economic sentiment, unemployment levels have all slightly improved over the prior quarter. Consumer confidence in the U.K. has reached a 13-year high in March, and U.K. retail sales also continue to gain momentum with spending data in the U.K. showing that first quarter retail sales growth of 3.8% is up from the 3.6% in the fourth quarter. 
And MasterCard's total European volume growth for the first quarter was in the mid-teens, processed transaction growth in the low 20s, very similar to the last quarter. 
Latin America, that continues to be challenged economically, and our first quarter and postnatal for Brazil showed retail sales growth basically flat. And that's down from the almost 1% growth in the fourth quarter and as the Brazilian economy settles into some form of recession and unemployment levels are continuing to rise. Lower oil prices are also slowing Mexico's economic recovery, but there, consumer spending has held steady. And the region's annual GDP growth is now expected to be around 0.8%, and that's down slightly from the earlier projections of 1%. 
But despite those challenges, our business in the region remain solid. First quarter GDV and processed transaction growth is in the mid-teens, which is the same last last quarter. 
In Asia-Pacific, business sentiment is currently held steady in the first quarter, led by the continued optimism of Indian companies about economically funds, but way down by the Chinese economic slowdown. Consumer confidence across the region is still highly, despite some recent declines, and our business in the region is continuing to do well. GDV growth in the mid-teens the same as last quarter. Processed transaction growth of the low 20s, down slightly from the last quarter. 
So overall, when you put all this together, economic environment in the U.S. and Europe are showing signs of improvement, but challenges still remain in some areas of Latin America and the Asia-Pacific region. 
and our business continues to be impacted by the strong U.S. dollar, but the underlying fundamentals of our business remain strong and we run the business for those underlying fundamentals, and that's what's going to help us navigate through these economic and dollar challenges. 
So before we go to our business highlights, let me quickly update you on the European regulatory matters on Russia and on China. So I'll start with the European registration related to the card payments. The European Parliament and the Council of Ministers have signed the final text. We expect official publication of the legislation in the next couple of weeks. Interchange caps will become effective 6 months later, so sometime towards the end of the year. And all other parts of the legislation will apply starting 12 months after the effective date, so we are talking mid-2016 for that. 
In Russia, we've actually successfully migrated our local card transactions to the new domestic NSPK platform by the April 1 deadline. And we were the first network to do so. The network requirements of the Russian the legislation will have no service disruption to card orders and without searching domestic transactions through area, but we're continuing to provide all the value-added services to our customers through our direct capabilities. In terms of the financial impact to our business, no change in our previous estimate of something less than $50 million on an annualized basis of additional costs. 
Last week, as you all read, China announced that international payment companies, like MasterCard, will be allowed to establish domestic switching operations in China. Of this security a large opportunity for us over the next long-term decade or whichever way you look at it, it's a great opportunity. It's a large marketplace, and they're keen to play there, and we are encouraged by the announcement. We want to switch domestic transaction in China. As soon as possible, we want to leverage the investments we already made in that market. But having said that, there are number of steps that need to be completed before we reach that point. Detailed regulations are yet to be issued. Some combination of the people Bank of China and the China Banking Regulatory Commission will put out the details originations over the next data of time. It's unclear to me exactly when those will get published. We will need to then submit a license application. Clearly, they're already preparing that, so we can go over that as soon as the regulations are issued. Then, we'll meet to work with government, get their application up, satisfy the detailed requirements of the regulations, so we don't really know how long that process will take for sure. But we do know some of the requirements already today, so there is, for example, a capital commitment required to the tune of roughly USD 160 million. We also know we'll need to provide some form of unsourced switching. And as you know, we have distributed network processes, but in addition to those, we have been investing on soil in China over the last period of time. We will need to assess the extent to which those existing investments already satisfy what regulations need and do whatever else is required to meet their needs, and then we will be the right place to be able to fully capable -- to be able to fully capable of taking advantage of these new domestic switching regulations. 
So all that said, the full requirements only to become clear when these detailed relations are issued. I kind of think that we should expect to be in a position to switch in China sometime toward the end of 2016. And obviously, as it moves more quickly, that's great for us. But in the meantime, there's a lot of people in the company working very hard to get ready for this opportunity to take advantage of it as soon as we possibly can. 
So recent business activity. During the quarter, we signed a number of new agreements and renewals supporting the expansion of our business around the world, and let me give you a few examples. The first, we enhanced our global partnership at Citi. City, as you know, is the world's largest credit card issuer. They have got a new an expanded 10-year agreement to move all that proprietary consumer credit and debit card portfolios to MasterCard. In Brazil, we signed a new 20-year agreement with Ita, and that further strengthens our long-term strategic relationship with the institution that is truly our largest customer in the Latin American region. And this agreement increases our share of Ita's credit, debit and prepaid portfolios. It gives us exclusive rights to switch all of the domestic and international transactions, allows us to create a new payment network in Brazil jointly with Ita and us. Of course, that's subject -- the last part is subject to getting regulatory approval. But overall, we are very pleased with this opportunity to be a stronger partner of both Citibank and Ita's. 
In the meanwhile, we signed new agreements of a Berkeley card in the U.K. They're converting a significant part of that commercial card business to MasterCard. In Ireland, we signed with the Bank of Ireland to convert the commercial and consumer credit portfolios to MasterCard. Having these deals should help us substantially increase our share in the commercial credit market in the U.K. and our overall credit share in Ireland. 
In New Zealand, Westpac and New Zealand are going to convert the points of both credit and commercial programs to MasterCard branded courts. So developments in different parts of the world. 
Meanwhile, we're continuing we did on our innovation efforts across the digital space. And starting with MasterPass. Last quarter, I mentioned our MasterPass platform was live in 16 countries around the world. And I'm very pleased to share that we since added Korea to the list of live markets, as well as more than doubled our global merchant acceptance of MasterPass to nearly 1.25 million merchants, and there are more in the pipeline, on those [indiscernible] more to come. 
So some specific examples of our progress include: We announced a 3-year strategic partnership and relationship with McDonald's in the U.A.E. and across 14 key markets in Middle East, Africa and Europe. And what we're doing with them is introducing contactless payments in their restaurants and enabling MasterPass for online ordering. One of the area of MasterPass is gaining momentum is transit. We just recently announced the global partnership with cubic transportation systems that are leading provider for smart city transit solutions in London and Chicago and other such cities. As part of their agreement, MasterPass will be integrated with Kubrick's ticketing and journey planning up, which already means we'll have to accelerate conversion of cash payments in transit into these digital payments. 
So quick service restaurants, the McDonald's example, transit systems, the cubic example, here are just 2 of what we are doing to extend our reach in cash. Couple of other examples that always mobile point of sales. Remember that mobile is not just about underlying consumers to make payments with their phones. It is actually bit in even more interesting option is to involve expanding acceptance to merchants who previously have no ability to take electronic payments to standard POS terminals. You had a number of those mobile point-of-sale rollout this quarter. In Nigeria, we part to the first bank of Nigeria and the guaranteed trust back. we've got MTOS devices to micro small and medium businesses that accept card transactions for the first time. In Hungary, we partnered with the insurance company of ligands to provide their sales agent with an MTOS device that accepts chip and contactless cards, submissively that client don't need to make cash payments at a post office or through a bank transfer. They can use that card and MPOS device that's with the insurance agent. 
So beginning in the mobile front. We all launch of Apple payment interest. And as you know, there were the first digital giant to enter that space. And as you know, the new Apple Watch has Apple Pay capabilities built into it. But in March, we also announced that we're working with Samsung to enable Samsung Pay, which will soon launch in the United States. 
You probably heard us talk about the factor of the technology agnostic when it comes to mobile and digital payments and we've determined to support implementations based on different market models. And one of the first implementations of the cloud-based mobile solution is that Bank of Australia, which has recently launched the tap and paid mobile payment solution across Android devices. 
Another example of a different mobile model is our recently announced agreement with the Egyptian government that we will extend financial services to more than 54 million Egyptians, but providing a platform that links of their national ID with the first national mobile wallet. included in the program is the financial inclusion aspect, but it's much broader because it provides every Egyptian  citizen with the tools to electronically receive government payments at a companion card to be used and purchases, bill payments, domestic evidences. 
And finally, a little word about our recent announcement about the intention to acquire Applied Predictive Technologies. APT is a leading cloud-based analytics company that platform basically enables companies across a number of industries to use their own data to accurately measure the profit impact of marketing, of merchandising, of operations, of capital initiatives. And last quarter, we talked about the acquisition of 5 1, a retail consulting and analytics firm. And by adding APT's capabilities with 5 1, what we're trying to do is advance capably to deliver differentiated products to merchants. And on analytic and consulting capabilities, in our own shop, along with our global footprint, will allow for the expansion of APT's platform and, of course, 5 1s, that's a for both of us. So we expect to complete this APT acquisition sometime over the second quarter. 
With that, I will turn it over to Martina for an update on our financial results and operating metrics. Martina?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ajay, and good morning, everyone picnic begin on Page 3 of our slide deck, where you can see the difference between as reported and FX adjusted growth rate for this quarter. Although the Brazilian real have some impact, the differential was prim
componenttext:
Thanks, Ajay, and good morning, everyone picnic begin on Page 3 of our slide deck, where you can see the difference between as reported and FX adjusted growth rate for this quarter. 
Although the Brazilian real have some impact, the differential was primarily driven by the euro-U.S. based dollar exchange rate. So here, you can see EPS growth continues to be strong at 22% on an as-reported basis and 29% after adjusting for currency. Continued revenue momentum, good cost controls and executing on our tax strategies and the current share repurchase program all contributed to that performance. 
I'd like to point out a few items here and then I talk about the major P&L line items in the subsequent slides. So first of all,, acquisitions that we made in 2014 drove $0.02 of dilution. Second, you can see the tax rate was favorable at 23.9% in the quarter, primarily due to our continued focus on initiatives to better align our tax structure with our business footprint, as well as a discreet item that resulted in our ability to claim foreign tax credit in the U.S. of this quarter. Third, share repurchases contributed $0.03 per share. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 11 million shares as a cost of about $947 million. And through April 22, we have purchased an additional 2.7 million shares at a cost of approximately $240 million. And we now have 2.8 billion remaining under the current authorization. 
Lastly, cash flow from operations was a little over $911 million. We ended the quarter with cash, clash equivalents and other liquid investments of about $5.9 billion. 
So let me turn to Page 4. Here, you can see as usual our operational metrics for the first quarter. Our gross dollar volume or GDV was up 12% on a local currency basis, down slightly from last quarter. Overall, our U.S. GDV was 7%, made up of credit and debit growth of 5% and 8%, respectively. Total U.S. GDV was about 1% down from last quarter, primarily due to the increased headwinds from lower gas prices. Set differently, this means that gas had a 2 PPT impact in the first quarter of 2015 versus a 1 PPT impact in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Outside of the U.S., volume growth was 15% on a local currency basis, about the same as last quarter and primarily driven by Turkey, Sweden and Canada. Cross-border volume, you can see grew 19% on a local currency basis, and that is the same of what we saw in the fourth quarter, which continues to be primarily driven by Europe. Growth in Europe was in the low 20s with the U.K., Germany, Italy and Sweden as key contributors to the growth. 
On Page 5, you see processed transactions grew 12% globally to $11 billion, and we continue to see double-digit growth in most regions. Growth increased from the 11% that we saw in the fourth quarter, primarily due to Europe and it was again driven by Sweden, Russia, Poland and Netherlands, similar to last quarter. 
Globally, the number of cards grew 8% with $2.2 billion MasterCard and branded cards. 
I'm now turning to Page 6 for highlights of view of the revenue line items. Net revenue growth was 3% as reported or 8% when you adjust for currency. This differential is due to the currency headwinds, primarily from the euro-U.S. based dollar exchange rate. Additionally, the impact of local currency exchange rates was about 2 PPT headwind. Acquisitions also contributed a little more than 2 PPT to the net revenue growth. And after you exclude the impact of both local and functional currencies, as well as the impact of acquisitions, we saw underlying net revenue growth of 8%. This reflects the underlying volume performance we expected, as well as a higher level of rebates and incentives that I talked about on our last earnings call. Specifically, rebates and incentives grew 25% in line with our expectations, primarily driven by the front-loaded impact over the life of the contract from certain customer renewals, which, Ajay mentioned in his comments. 
Now let me look it be at the other individual revenue line items on an FX adjusted basis. Domestic assessments grew 8%, while worldwide GDV grew 12%. This 4 PPT gap is primarily due to the impact of local currency, somewhat offset by pricing. Cross-border volume fees grew 9%, but cross-border grew 9%. Of the 10 PPT gap, the majority is due to a higher mix of inter-Europe activity, as well as some local currency impact. Transaction processing fees grew 13%, primarily driven by the 12% growth in processed transactions. 
And finally, other revenues grew 29%, which continues to be driven largely by contributions from our pinpoint acquisition, as well as our advisers business. 
Moving on to Page 7. You can see that total operating expenses decreased 1% in the quarter but increased 3% on an FX adjusted basis. Overall, M&A activities contributed 9 PPT to total expense growth. 
So let me spend a minute on G&A, which grew only 1% year-over-year, and explain how that happened. First, we continue to organically invest in our strategic initiatives, while managing our expenses very carefully. As a result, the underlying level of G&A expense grew 2 PPT this quarter. Second, acquisitions added 10 PPT to this growth quarter. This is in the G&A line, as we made a number of acquisitions in the second half of last year, which haven't yet last into our base run rate. However, these factors were offset by 2 FX related gains that were $69 million higher than last year or 11 PPT, and thus lowered overall G&A expense growth to 1%. 
The first was FX gains related to our normal hedging activities, mainly due to the depreciating U.S. dollar. and the second was a balance sheet remeasurement again, primarily related to the devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar. 
With that, let me turn to Slide 8 and let's discuss what we have seen in April through the 21st. Most of our business drivers are similar to what we experienced in the first quarter. The numbers through April 21 are as follows. Starting with processed volume, we saw a global growth of 10%, similar to the first quarter. In the U.S., our processed volume grew 4%, the same as what we saw last quarter, including run rate, a 2 PPT impact from lower gas prices. Processed volume outside the U.S. grew 16%, about 1 PPT lower than the first quarter, with growth of mid to high teens in each region. 
And globally, processed transaction growth was 12% and that's similar to what we saw in the first quarter, with double-digit growth in all regions except the U.S, which grew in the mid-single digits. And with respect to cross-border, our volumes grew at 17% globally, down 2 PPT from our first quarter growth. While the U.S. saw somewhat under growth in April, most other regions saw a deceleration. 
Looking ahead, let me start with some commentary about full year 2015. Given the continued strength of the U.S. dollar impacting many U.S. multinationals, including us, I'm going to start by summarizing our thoughts about FX. And remember, currency impacts us in 2 ways: First, since the beginning of the year, the significant depreciation of the euro and the real, the Brazilian real, versus the U.S. dollar, has increased the impact of the functional FX translation since my January commentary. If the rates for our functional currencies remain similar to where we are today -- they are today, that the euro trading at the EUR 1.09 level and the Brazilian real at the BRL 2.94 for the rest of the year, the net impact of the euro and real would be a 6 to 8 PPT headwind, mostly from the euro actually to our as-reported results for the full year. And it's depending on what line item we are talking about. So revenue, net income or EPS. 
Second, we have the impact of local currency rates, relatively to the functional currencies. And we continue to expect some net headwind throughout the year, both to revenue and the bottom line. And based on the current rates, this is still likely to be in the 2 PPT range, similar to our estimate in late January. The impact of this is already included in our FX adjusted guidance. 
At current FX rates, both of these impacts will provide a headwind of about $700 million to net revenue and about $300 million to net income for full year 2015. 
So with that as a backdrop, now let me get into some specific P&L line items. Our underlying business remain strong. However, some components of our 2015 outlook have changed due to the impact of FX, that I just talked about, and our latest acquisition, Applied Predictive Technologies or APT. On an FX adjusted basis, we continue to expect high single-digit net revenue growth for 2015, including roughly 2 PPT from our M&A transactions. We're seeing good traction for many of our recent portfolio wins and new product initiatives. However, revenue growth will be impacted by some items specific to 2015, which we highlighted back in January. The first, as we have already seen in the first quarter, a couple of significant contract renewals that provide the foundation for future growth come with the front-loaded incentives over the life of the contract than our typical agreements. And the next 3 quarters will reflect that, too. 
Second, while the Chase conversion to a competitor is essentially no complete, we will continue to see the lapping impact over the remainder of 2015. So on an as-reported basis, the net revenue growth rates will now likely be in the low single-digit range as a result of the stronger FX headwinds than we forecasted at the beginning of the year, primarily from the euro functional translation. And based on the current FX rates, this will be about a 6 PPT impact. 
Moving to rebates and incentives. Let me direct some questions we've been getting about what we mean by you front-loaded incentives. This is a reference to tinkering more incentives in the earlier years of a contract. Also, with the recent signings, we now expect full year 2015 rebate and incentive growth to be similar to what we saw in Q1 with as somewhat harder growth rate in the second quarter. 
Overall, we now project the growth rate for total operating expenses to full year 2015 to be in the mid-single digits on an FX adjusted basis. And this continues to be predominantly due to the roughly 7 PPT impact from our announced M&A activities, with more of that impact occurring in the first half of the year. However, as-reported expense growth will now likely be in the low single-digit range after considering a roughly 4 PPT tailwind from the euro and the real translation. 
Let me give you an update on potential dilution from M&A activities, with the expected addition of APT by the end of the second quarter. We now project total EPS dilution would be about $0.11 to $0.13 to for full year 2015. Less than half of the expected diffusion is due to the amortization of acquired intangible. 
As I said in the last quarter, you should assume a full year 2015 tax rate of about 28%. That has not changed, but it's due to the continued benefit we expect from the tax initiative I discussed in our January earnings call. 
And given all the detail I just went through, let me just step back and summarize a bit here. The continue to expect solid fundamentals that drive our underlying business in 2015 and that's despite a mixed economic environment, as well as of the more significant headwinds from FX than we expected back in January. As you can see, we continue to sign customer contracts and we continue to invest in the right strategic areas, while managing our expenses prudently. 
Finally, let me move on to our long-term performance objectives of 2013 to '15 for that period, which remained unchanged from what I said on our year-end earnings call back in late January. Given our expectations for 2015 revenue growth, we expect to deliver our low-end of the 11% to 14% net revenue CAGR range. We continue to expect at least 20% EPS CAGR for the 3-year period due continued expense management, as well as benefits from our lower tax rate and share repurchases. And we will remain committed to our annual operating margin target of at least 50%. Just remember, these objectives are on a constant currency basis and they do exclude our 2014 M&A activities, as well as any new ones that might occur this year. 
As far as owning our performance objectives forward, again, nothing different from what I said in January. The overall growth prospects for the payments industries have not changed. The underlying drivers of our business remain solid and we are expanding our reach in areas that we're strategically targeting, such as processing, the guilty, information services and all things digital. We will provide you with our new long-term objective before the end of this year, most likely at our Investor Day in September. 
Now let me turn the call back to Barbara to begin the Q&A session. Barbara?

componenttext: I just wanted to ask Ajay about the APT acquisition. I just that 3-minute summary of their website is very helpful. I was wondering how you'll sell it? Is that going to sold to MasterCard consulting? Or will that be embraced by your bank partners for resale into the channel?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's depends on which kind of product you're referring to. APT has products that go to merchants. They go to banks, they go to consumer product companies, depending on what kind of need for analytical capability that company has. A large part of that curr
componenttext: It's depends on which kind of product you're referring to. APT has products that go to merchants. They go to banks, they go to consumer product companies, depending on what kind of need for analytical capability that company has. A large part of that current client base is merchants, in which case, they have their 2 methods getting out there. One is their own sales force, which essentially reaches merchants and thus the analytical capability like us offset the service provider, as provide on the computer screens of individuals in the merchant management system. And the other way, of course, will be through our own sales force in our advisers and information services business, where we believe we can add value to what they're doing. So the idea is to you put sales forces, but to embed the capability in the clients end-use systems by embedding the Software-as-a-Service approach to the business. That's what APT does. It's a little different from the way we do our current data stuff, which tends to be more engagement by engagement, and that's the difference in the 2 models. And I think that's for both in growing big data market.

And this was driven essentially by their hope to go public and want to be comparable. Can you confirm if that's the case because it's a little hard to actually confirm that?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'd like the fact that you started singing question in China. You must be the only guy who think China is answerable in quick questions, right? But I -- Craig, the fact is that the data around China and the current economic of the domestic payment
componenttext: Yes. So I'd like the fact that you started singing question in China. You must be the only guy who think China is answerable in quick questions, right? But I -- Craig, the fact is that the data around China and the current economic of the domestic payment system, which is asking about, is opaque because that is a public data obviously available. But what I do know from all the many trips I've but make and then a better part of 10 to 12 years is that interchange rates on domestic transactions tend to be lower than the interchange rates that you would see on the average across the world in both credit and debit. You need to know that credit domestically is much smaller than debit today. And in fact, the largest use of payment cards domestically in China today is to take out cash from an ATM. And an even larger use is for the cards to remain dormant. This is the marketplace of that is ready in spending activity on cards across all categories. It's a marketplace with a very large domestic card issuance with a fairly large dormant card base with what is used -- being used for taking out cash sort of ATM on a bank branch rather than the point-of-sale use with lower credit use than debit. It's a typical early-stage electronic payments developing market with 1 dynamic, which is an interchange rate, are lower than you would normally expected. Network economics depend on what you were able to strike deals with a different issuers and merchants. I'm going to reserve my judgment and that I get my chance to really get into those deals because right now, they don't have those deals. our deals tend to be on cross-border use of these cards, both outward and inward. And so we grabbed we can see how it goes. But there's no denying one big enormous volume you can get and if European is constructed like us where we have a relatively low variable cost per transaction, that is an attractive opportunity. There's no denying that because you need to know a lot of work with insurers, you need to do a lot of work with merchants and acquire us to drive acceptance. There's a lot of things to be done over the next few years, but I see it as a really large and interesting opportunity for companies like ours.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Sanjay, back to your question on economics. We talked a little bit about the venue where the U.S. results. I've seen like consumer optimistic because they think serving so from that gas prices. Although gas price substantially. And if you did an avera
componenttext: And Sanjay, back to your question on economics. We talked a little bit about the venue where the U.S. results. I've seen like consumer optimistic because they think serving so from that gas prices. Although gas price substantially. And if you did an average individual households math, you are probably putting between $8 million and $10 million from the spending on gas, which could be available to go into other avenues. So they're optimistic because if you left that money in that pocket. What they're doing with it, is there pay down some debt, which you can see in the numbers on consumer debt across the country, both in revolving debt, but also into personal and secured loans. And also, to an extent, in mortgages. And then you can see that some of the market is printed -- the savings rate and saving rates, I think, in March has high as 5.8%. They've gone down to 2% 6, 7 months ago. As you remember, just after the crisis, they were at 6% and 7%. So I don't know the 5.8% is a bad thing for the country for the long term by the way. Probably a good thing. But probably not all the money is coming out into goods and services spending, so when a company like ours because we don't really get any benefit out of all higher spending rate directly, we don't get any benefit out of a high saving rates directly. we also getting the benefit out of lower pay down of that. We don't get me any benefit. We get benefit when this spend. And overall spending is not going in the form that you would see it once you added gas back in. That's what we're seeing. Now it doesn't -- an amount into this, which that luxury good sales and you can see in the results there are number of other luxury goods of retailers, recently, others like that. Their sales are not going the way they were 6, 8 months ago. And most of that, I think, is caused by the fact that inbound tourist arrivals into the U.S. and their spending patterns, given the relative strength of the dollar to the euro, the Japanese yen, the Brazilian real, the people who are spending of course, Russian coming in as much as they were some time ago, all that is impacting luxury good spending, which also, by the way, feeds them to the total retail spend numbers. So that's a little extra digging probably more than you wanted, but that's what's going on. Now I don't see that as a long-term issue. I actually not even a medium term issue. I think easy to reason probably improving over the next few months. I think you'll see Americans traveling out in the summer. I think you'll see others coming in and they're coming in somewhat different pattern of consumer spending over the next 2 to 6 months, just because underlying consumer sentiment is positive. So that's I see right now.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first one, I mean, the rate card there's no discussion right now because we have all gone including our competitors. We both said, there is no implementation of that rate card till 2016, at least in January. That's what we said. The idea right now is t
componenttext: So first one, I mean, the rate card there's no discussion right now because we have all gone including our competitors. We both said, there is no implementation of that rate card till 2016, at least in January. That's what we said. The idea right now is to ensure tokenization gets adopted in the market. And remember, even if you do something in January, with the tokenization rates, right now, to is only going in for transactions over the form of a mobile phone kind of transactions. And as you know, from your own research and details on this, that's still a small parts of total expenditure and transactions in the United States. So I'd just like to put that genie in a bottle where it belongs. It's very important. It's very critical for securitizing -- for security digital transactions. No doubt, it's got an implementation time line, which will take some time for it to become more ubiquitous than just the phone-based transaction today. That's the concepts I'd like to put it in. We are very committed to it. They're investing a large amount of money in ensuring our capabilities in it. they're investing money and rolling it out into other markets overseas and different people claim different dates and reach the markets. I will tell you, discount all that that you see it in the market, this is not an easy thing to get done. It's not an easy thing to roll out. So we're working very hard on that. As far as the actual adoption by merchants of different -- or the request by merchants think about different interchange rates their budget, look at the end of the day, this card-not-present rate from the can't presently, both have been applying for a period of time. If digitization were to become ubiquitous, will there be a change in those 2 buckets of rates?  Will there be a third with 1 move down, 1 move up? Or there be 4, 5 different buckets, that's just speculation right now. We are far away from a stage. tokenize transactions comprise an adequate percentage of the total to drive great changes in the marketplace, other than the excitement around finally getting a really secured system for digital transactions.

componenttext: Could you just talk about G&A expense and as you look out over the course of the year, where you are still investing? And where you might have growth? And then wonder, Martina, you could clarify again the charge for the Bolivar?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all on G&A, as a said, on an ethics adjusted basis, so full year 2015, you should expect the mid-single-digit kind of range. And that is predominantly driven by the 7 PPT impact from all of our announced M&A activities. So of course, we a
componenttext: Yes. So first of all on G&A, as a said, on an ethics adjusted basis, so full year 2015, you should expect the mid-single-digit kind of range. And that is predominantly driven by the 7 PPT impact from all of our announced M&A activities. So of course, we are going to organically invest in all of our strategic areas that are card out, the processing area, the loyalty area. You just saw that we did in the acquisition in the information services area. So of course, we are going to do that, but we're going to do that with a very astute and careful Expense Management that we have put into the company. So that's our put together. It gets to that mid-single digit growth number for the year. In terms of the Venezuelan bolivar, so a couple of things on that. First of all, part of our business in Venezuela is in bolivars. Part of our board business in Venezuela is in U.S. dollars. The business that we have in bolivars in Venezuela is done as such as we can take the bolivars out of the country, right? The currency has currency restrictions. So what we have engaged like any other multinationals, international hedging strategies that allow us over time to be protecting the investment that we have in this country. Part of that hedging strategy involves for us to actually take up a loan sometime ago where we bought some real property in the country. And what happens when you have a devaluation of that currency of the Bolivar, is you actually having to devalue that monetary asset to loan, and that was also the gain. That gain is basically buffering. The impact that we will be having from the Bolivar devaluation on our revenues for the year, that's about a $40 million impact to our top line that's all included in the discussions that I have with you this morning for 2015 revenues. But that's how this works.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess maybe taking both of these items together, both your kind of investment and expenses related to the acquisitions and the rebates and incentives for these deals, could you talk a little bit about the payback period for those 2 things? And how we ca
componenttext: I guess maybe taking both of these items together, both your kind of investment and expenses related to the acquisitions and the rebates and incentives for these deals, could you talk a little bit about the payback period for those 2 things? And how we can see that impact kind of revenues in future years?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, on the M&A investments, what we are typically targeting is -- so first of all, we're looking at every M&A transaction from a discounted cash flow analysis, right? And we typically like to see a pay back over a Tier 2 or 3-year period
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, on the M&A investments, what we are typically targeting is -- so first of all, we're looking at every M&A transaction from a discounted cash flow analysis, right? And we typically like to see a pay back over a Tier 2 or 3-year period from a cash flow point of view. That does not necessarily narrow the accounting view, simply because accounting is done differently than what you see coming through in the cash. But again, and we've said it a numbers of people, we try to hope to get to the dilution impact of no more than 2 years. And so you should be seeing these acquisitions coming to fruition, the 2014 acquisition sometime later in 2016, as well as the 2015 acquisitions that we're doing, which APT is the big one at this point in time. You would be seeing that coming through later in 2017. So that's how we think about acquisition. From a rebates and incentive point of view, I'll just have to remind you every deal is different, right? We have 1,000 of deals, every deal is different. Every year, we're writing hundreds of deals. When you look at some deals, you can get out quick payback, it could be in the 6, 7, 9 months period, but it also depends when you have cards converting or whether you have that portfolio already and you're do just making out of the portfolio, i.e. encouraging more volume in transactions coming on. Some of the bigger deals might have a longer payback because you have to do certain investments in order to encourage that portfolio to behave the way that you would like it to behave. So it's -- mostly, I have to tell you, it's a fairly wide range in terms of the payback calculation.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Every deal has a payback that calculation of this they come, but it's not something you can generalize from easily. And I think the second part to the conversation are earlier about acquisitions because I have been asked this once or twice. Remember that
componenttext: Every deal has a payback that calculation of this they come, but it's not something you can generalize from easily. And I think the second part to the conversation are earlier about acquisitions because I have been asked this once or twice. Remember that when we talked about our guidance x acquisitions, by the time the second year of our deal is complete, that acquisition is in our base. It is part of what we run. So I'm not asking for a way to x acquisitions into infinity. It's too early for an acquisition. So Martina something in this conversation about the 2014 acquisition is what she's excluding from the guidance because of '14 and '15, we didn't do that 2-year period. The deals we did before that has a prepaid worldwide, which is taken from travel x or DataCash that we bought or other of that type are all in our base. And frankly, without access prepaid worldwide, I doubt we will have achieved the kind of success we've achieved on our prepaid business over the last 5 years as we've gone from a small market share to one of the largest players in the business around the world today. So we get to think back and it's just that we kind of make sure you understand that our guidance is exclusing them for 2 years because I don't know what deal I'm going to do when I give you the guidance for the 2 years. What I'm trying to do.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Darrin, let me take your first question. Every quarter every year, we're assigning agreements. And they're all incremental to our base. So if you were to see drop in the rebates and incentives, quite frankly, I would be worried about it. You only -- you d
componenttext: Darrin, let me take your first question. Every quarter every year, we're assigning agreements. And they're all incremental to our base. So if you were to see drop in the rebates and incentives, quite frankly, I would be worried about it. You only -- you don't see a vibrant business if we continue to add to what we need to do from a stock point of view on the deal side. And that will involve generally and you've seen it over the last 7 years, adding to rebates and incentives. The other thing that you need to remember how we construct our deals. Our deals has constructed in such a way that we give higher rebates incentives for those clients will deliver more volume and transactions to us. So as volumes and transactions go up, mostly on the volume side, little bit less on the transaction side, you will be naturally the seeing the rebates and rebates like floating up.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you're also asking ask a question will that 25 kind of percent growth rate be something that stay over the next 3 years through quarters because a bunching here with that growth rate that we use in the future. I think it's tough to say that to you beca
componenttext: So you're also asking ask a question will that 25 kind of percent growth rate be something that stay over the next 3 years through quarters because a bunching here with that growth rate that we use in the future. I think it's tough to say that to you because of what Martina just explain because these deal flowing through and that can second question about do I see does coming over the next 2 or 3 years? I ensure I'm not doing it because otherwise, I would not do anything for the next 3 years. But the fact is that I really can't tell you what those are at this stage. No idea. It will come when they come. But the good news is, I would intelligently think about the rebates and incentives as good collateral. When you get a deal dot and if it's frontloaded as in the couple of these, that's actually also in the bad thing today. Now accounting could change and accounting could cause lots of for everybody about frontloading versus the loading. And frankly, I don't -- I try to stay away from all the accounting stuff when you do this and stay with the logic of what a customer is looking for and what our relationship with that customer will be and what the franchise value of that there will be and what the revenue growth over the life of that be would be and with the profitability or the life of that deal will be and what the extra value-added service we sell into the client or the life of the deal will be. Those conversations I'm happy to go have every day.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, on our 2013 and '15 revenue objectives, yes, they're going to come in at the low end of the range. We are not coming in below. we're coming at the low end of the range. And as you could see in 2013 and '14, we performed above the range. And
componenttext: First of all, on our 2013 and '15 revenue objectives, yes, they're going to come in at the low end of the range. We are not coming in below. we're coming at the low end of the range. And as you could see in 2013 and '14, we performed above the range. And this year, for a number of factors, we will be a little bit below the range. But when you added it all up, it will be at the range. In terms of the factors where we're performing a little bit below the range this year, 1 local FX impact, right? I mean, you saw that very clearly. That is a big impact, it's 2 PPT at this point in time on the top line. Yes, it gets somewhat offset by the expense line. And you can actually see from an EPS point of view we're navigating through that headwind relatively though. Secondly, when you look at gas prices, right? Gas prices have a big impact. You guys know from a volume and a transaction point of view in the United States, it's really important to be looking at that. And we're going to fair through something like that, too. And those are, I think, the 2 big ones. And then...

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I would add to that is you know we told you that we got this particular year this are coming frontloaded. And so that has a minor impact. But you don't conclude that it's all due to the economy. Its, first of all, struggling to those F
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I would add to that is you know we told you that we got this particular year this are coming frontloaded. And so that has a minor impact. But you don't conclude that it's all due to the economy. Its, first of all, struggling to those FX rates. There's a lot there because we talk to you x FX takes out the real and the euro, but above all the other currencies and we work our away through all those times. So that's kind of big chunk in there. And, of course, the gas here. This all the economic ups and downs. But to try to figure out where this is going, we're is this going to get to do when we do Investor Day. But I don't see and neither is Martina any fundamental change in the underlying dynamics of the kind of business we're doing this year versus the prior 2 years, not at all.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give a little color on some of the mix of the growth of your business, if you would, like now the large commercial has been a big growth driver for you guys. In the U.S., do you see the US. When you seeing any or globally any differ
componenttext: I was hoping you could give a little color on some of the mix of the growth of your business, if you would, like now the large commercial has been a big growth driver for you guys. In the U.S., do you see the US. When you seeing any or globally any different trends on the large commercial versus small business? And then are you seeing prepaid still a big global growth driver?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So commercial is a driver still across the world. It's not just large commercial. Inside our commercial business, it certainly is some of the large commercial businesses, but also there's all the small business and there's portions of business that doing
componenttext: So commercial is a driver still across the world. It's not just large commercial. Inside our commercial business, it certainly is some of the large commercial businesses, but also there's all the small business and there's portions of business that doing  where we use MasterCard virtual card number capability to intervene in the flow between businesses. So there's a number of things inside the commercial business. And maybe over the -- one of the things we could do at Investor Day is to give you guys a little more insight into the different things that were doing around the commercial business. And we probably should do that. But it got more and then just commercial insight. I actually continue to believe that we have a real opportunity for growth as a company in that space because we have  a series of good assets that we put together from our virtual card number capability to our ability with acceptance being superior to that of certain other brands, which remain unnamed, to our ability to do business across the world with 1 technology across all the regions. There's a number of advantages of their, which I actually believe commercial has and we can play with it. It's a data capability with smart data. It's a whole series of these. So I still think of that is a big and decent opportunity. On prepaid, yes, prepaid has been going well over the last 3 to 4 years. I just refer to prepaid and we talked about the acquisitions and the healthy from Access Prepaid worldwide to help us in the prepaid program management business. I consider that to be an opportunity still for various reasons. One of those is there's an increasing design across the world to get to the underserved in financial inclusion terms. Clearly, prepaid this the best product in some form or the other, with the deliver court or deliver through the phone or delivered through a fingerprint to that population. It reduces the risk, it's more appropriate for governments to transfer. Benefits, it's better for NGOs. I think you'll see the numbers go there. Those tend to come with lower economics because those people to take out cash first and use it at a point of sale later in the development cycle. This low part of our percentage. So yes, we're getting a mix of growth from commercial and prepaid. And I think commercial will keep going and I think prepaid will different economics from commercial.

componenttext: Yes. It's something we'd like to do more of an like to encourage in some cases and also having so we end up with the benefit of having 2 brand strategy in debit. Great. Well, thank you, all, for question and we'll leave with a couple of closing parts. We just talked about this in the Q&A, but the world economy continues to be complicated and things completely but the U.S. looks to be in better shape and people are getting spending all the savings from lower gas prices as explaining in the sponsor Sanjay's question, but it's there. They're spending excess gas and I believe you will see improvements in there. I think Europe is slowly improving, but the Russian economy remains challenged. And that's a fairly large economy around the world to have that challenging. In Asia and Latin America markets, we economics problems as well. Currency movements added to the challenges. I think we're managing our way through it with tight cost controls. The strong underlying dynamics of our business remain unchanged. Our momentum continues. we are launching new products. we are working with the digital giants. we are working with banks, getting new deals from them. We're building new relationships with merchants that acquiring things to help us cement those relationships. that's all good stuff. We are very focused on all the right things. And so thank you for your continued support of the company. Thank you for joining us today.
