headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the MasterCard Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Barbara Gasper, Head of Investor Relations, you
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the MasterCard Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you. Barbara Gasper, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for a discussion about our third quarter 2015 financial results. With me on the call today are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-Mejean, our Chief
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for a discussion about our third quarter 2015 financial results. With me on the call today are Ajay Banga, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Martina Hund-Mejean, our Chief Financial Officer.
Following comments from Ajay and Martina, the operator will announce your opportunity to get into the queue for the Q&A session. Up until then, no one is actually registered to ask a question. [Operator Instructions]
This morning's earnings release and the slide deck that will be referenced on this call can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website, mastercard.com. These documents include a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures to their GAAP equivalents and have also been attached to an 8-K that we filed with the SEC earlier this morning. A replay of this call will be posted on our website for one month.
Finally, as set forth in more detail in today's earnings release, I need to remind everyone that today's call may include some forward-looking statements about MasterCard's future performance. Actual performance could differ materially from what is suggested by our comments today. Information about the factors that could affect future performance are summarized at the end of our press release, as well as contained in our recent SEC filings.
And with that, I will now turn the call over to Ajay.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. With the backdrop of this continuing uncertainty in the global economy, we're actually quite pleased with our results this quarter. After adjusting for currency, we reported net revenue growth of 8%, in line wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Good morning, everybody. With the backdrop of this continuing uncertainty in the global economy, we're actually quite pleased with our results this quarter. After adjusting for currency, we reported net revenue growth of 8%, in line with what we talked we would get and an EPS growth of 11%. And this excludes the impact of a special item, and Martina will touch on that later.
So now let's take a quick look on what's going on in the global economy, and it's been challenged in recent months. And while the U.S. recovery remains among the most solid, job gains has steadily lowered the unemployment rate to just over 5%, but job and wage growth are starting to flow. Consumer confidence is only modestly up. And as you know, we have given yesterday's announcement, uncertainty of our rising interest rates remain.
So moving beyond the U.S. The economic picture is both mixed. Global growth are clearly slowing, particularly in smaller emerging markets, and the sharper then expected turnover in China is affecting many other economies. Exporters to China and those have closed trade links, Russia, Brazil, for example, would probably be the most impacted, adding to the downward pressure on oil and commodity prices.
In Asia, India is less dependent on global demand and should continue to grow. But in Australia, consumer and business sentiment has weakened again as their economic growth has slowed for what is now the fifth consecutive quarter. Growth in Europe, on the other hand, is improving, but not as fast as we have previously expected and the employment rate continue the gradual decline. The U.K. remains steady. Economic growth is expected to continue through the rest of this year and into next year. And Germany is also showing some signs of strengthening.
In Latin America, Brazil continues to be in a recession. Economic conditions continue to worsen in Venezuela. The lone bright spot there appears to be Mexico, where the economic recovery continues, led by relatively strong consumer spending and the lowest levels of inflation in almost 50 years.
So when you put all this together, what we're really talking about is some period of economic uncertainty fueled by the slowdown in China, combined with continued lower oil and commodity prices, as well as this continuing uncertainty of our rising interest rates in the U.S. And so overall, we remain cautious about the outlook for the global economy.
With all of this, our continues to grow. Our fundamentals remains strong. We're seeing double-digit volume and transaction growth across most of our markets as a result of our efforts to drive the shift from cash electronic payments, but also as well as our continued business growth.
So before we go to our business highlight, I want to say a few words about the opening of the Chinese domestic market. Since the final Chinese regulation has not yet been released, we have no new insights to add beyond what we already told you at our recent Investor Day last month. We continue to execute against our plans to be technically ready to process domestic Chinese transactions by the end of 2016, and we're working on expanding issuance and acceptance lead market while we wait for clarity on the regulations. So now into some of our recent business activity. You only heard a great deal from us at Investor Day. You had an opportunity to see first hand the number of products and service innovations we are rolling out. So let me just mention a couple of items very briefly.
First, we continue to grow in the co-brand space. In the United States, we are pleased to be able to confirm our agreement with Jet Flow to launch a new co-brand credit card and convert their existing credit card portfolio. Barclaycard will be the issuing bank.
We also won several other co-brand deals around the world, including CITS, that's the largest travel company in China; Kohl's, the largest supermarket chain in Australia; and of course, one of the co-brand for Airflow. Airflow have a number of co-brand. We've won one of those. They're the largest Russian airline, so probably no. We also sign as triple punch up with the Citi for an affluent co-brand with a large global airline based in the Middle East.
Moving beyond specific customer agreements, I'd like to talk a few minutes to you about some other developments going on in our space, in the payment space in particular. And let's start with EMV in the United States.
As you know, the liability shift went into effect October 1. We're kind of pleased with the progress we are seeing thus far. We now expect 60% of cards and approximately 40% of terminals in the United States to be chip capable by the end of this year. By the way, this is true for us, but it's true for the industry as a whole. We expect almost all cards in the market to be upgraded to chip by the end of 2017, and we've already seen tens of millions of chip transactions. 
By the way, as a little side benefit of EMV is that it will likely give a boost to the adoption of contactless or NFC payments because the latest generation of EMV enabled terminals also contain contactless capabilities. And that kind of leads me to the next topic I'd like to talk about, which to give you a quick update on the progress we have made in the digital space. 
Over the past year or so, you've heard us make several announcements relates to MasterPass. Just to put it together for you, with our live and 24 markets, we have accepted over 250,000 merchants. Unless which recently added Burger King and firearm subs. In addition, we recently announced massive will be fully tokenized using our MDES platform starting with the United States in 2016. And that will give consumers EMV level security and the ability to shop more securely online all in app from any device across all card types.
So let me give you one example of a breakthrough, which can really drive the growth of MasterPass. And despite the challenges going on recently in the Russian market, we are working hard to extend our capabilities there. And as recently, we just had a partnership and us with index money, one of the largest payment service providers in Russia, that sense of the use of MastePass to their 22 million customers. And talking about scale, the State Bank of India, which is the largest bank in that country, has got more than 15,000 plus branches, have also launched their mobile waller solutions with the help of MasterCard. And that solution enables consumers to load money, perform a B2B transfer, pay bills, think the average consumer in India is very keen to get with and the State Bank of India is the right partner for that.
And as you know, we've been putting a lot of emphasis on tokenizing transactions using MDES. And most recently, you heard about Android Pay and Samsung Pay, who we've added in the list of providers leveraging that service. And as said before, we were the first to extend support for private label cards. In fact, Kohl's and J.C. Penney have now gone live with that service. In addition to small business cards, we were also the first network to announce tokenization for all commercial cards. And all that means is that all of our card products in China can soon be tokenized. So it becomes ubiquitous for us.
We also announced the launch of our Digital Enablement Express program, which basically expedites the process of digitizing and tokenizing accounts using MDES. Any financial institution can gain immediate access to all our latest digital payment services. While our partners, that's digital wallet providers, device manufacturers, other digital payment providers, they can add on a simple on boarding process to engage with all these participating banks. Google, Samsung, Capital One, Fifth Third Bank, Key Bank, among the first companies to announce their participation in the express program.
Now the Internet of things, something everybody has been talking about, continuous the conversion for the physical and digital world that began in mobile devices. That new generation of connected devices, smart watches, wearables, this will collect and transmit vast amount of data. And the idea is we are able to use that to provide new insight, new services. To give you an example, data from a smartphone indicating that a consumer at a retail store location could trigger a discount offer for using their credit card. Now that sounds futuristic, but to help fulfill that feature, we actually just launched a new digital enablement program that return any excess to the available in top payment enabled device. That gives consumers the ability to shop using the thing that is most convenient to them with the highest level of security available.
That program will launch with the support of several marquee partners across multiple industries. Total types from a fashion designer, Adam [indiscernible] automakers, Joe motors, saw been in fashion Ben Wiggly, were all in display using our technology at Money 2020 just earlier this week. And we worked with NXP and Qualcomm to develop the technology, and Capital One is actually the first issuer to embrace it. In addition, Capital One has also announced the availability of contactless mobile payment capability to its wallet app. Had actually become so the first issuer in the United States to do so using our cloud-based payments technology.
And these announcements kind of endorse how we turn advance our digital strategy, eliminate the boundaries of our consumer space by delivering a secured digital payment experience to virtually anything. Every device can be a device of commerce. That's the idea. So mobility, cloud-based payments, the Internet of Things and big data are all coming together.
EMV, contactless and our MDES enabled secure transactions across all channels, all devices. And as new players enter the digital payment landscape, we continue to see our technology as of the foundation for new innovative payment services. 
And with that, I'm going to turn the call over to Martina to update on our financial results and operational metrics. Martina?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ajay, and good morning everyone. So let me begin on Page 3 of our slide deck, where you see the difference between non-GAAP reported and FX adjusted growth rates for this quarter. The differential continues to be primarily driven by the euro-U.S.
componenttext:
Thanks, Ajay, and good morning everyone. So let me begin on Page 3 of our slide deck, where you see the difference between non-GAAP reported and FX adjusted growth rates for this quarter. The differential continues to be primarily driven by the euro-U.S. dollar exchange rate. Now these figures also excludes the impact of a special item of $70 million on a pretax basis -- $79 million of a pretax basis taken in this quarter related to the termination of our U.S. employee pension plan.
I'd like to point out a few items here, and then I'll talk about the major P&L line items in subsequent slides. First, EPS growth was 5% or 11% after adjusting for currency. Continued revenue momentum, good cost control, executing on our attack strategies and repurchasing shares are contributed to that performance. And as expected, acquisitions that we made in 2014 and 2015 drove $0.03 of EPS dilution in the quarter. Second, the tax rate was 28.2% in the quarter, primarily due to our continued focus on better aligning our tax structure with our business footprint. Third, share repurchases contributed $0.02 per share to our third quarter results. As of October 22, we have $1.2 billion remaining on that one current authorization. And lastly, cash flow from operations was $1.3 billion. And we ended the quarter with cash, cash equivalents and other liquid investments of about $5.1 billion.
Well, let me turn to Page 4. And here, you can see the operational metrics for the second quarter. Worldwide gross dollar volume, or GDV, was up 13% on a local currency basis, and that's pretty much the same as the last quarter. Overall, our U.S. dollar GDV grew 8%, made up of credit and debit growth of 9% and 7%, respectively. Total U.S. GDV was up 1 ppt versus last quarter, with stronger growth in our consumer credit programs, offset by slightly lower growth in our debit programs, primarily due to lapping some debit wins and a continued 2 ppt headwind from lower gas prices.
Outside of the U.S., volume growth was 16% on a local currency basis. Again, same as the last quarter with mid to high-teens growth in each region. Cross-border volume grew 16% on a local currency basis, slightly lower than the 17% we saw in the second quarter, primarily driven by Europe.
Turning to Page 5. Here, you can see global processed transaction growth slowed slightly to 12% from the 13% we saw in the second quarter, primarily driven by fewer PIN POS transactions in the U.S. We continue to see double-digit growth in all other regions. And globally, the numbers of cards grew 8% with 2.2 billion MasterCard and Maestro-branded cards issued.
Now let's turn to Page 6 for highlights on a few of the revenue line items. Net revenue growth was 2%, as reported, or 8% FX adjusted, given currency headwinds. Additionally, the impact of local currency exchange rates was slightly higher than we expected at about 3 ppt, primarily driven by the Russian ruble to the euro and the Canadian dollar to the U.S. dollar exchange rates. After eliminating all impacts of currency, our underlying net revenue growth was 11%. And acquisitions contributed about 1 ppt to that net revenue growth.
Looking strictly at the individual revenue line items on an FX adjusted basis. So domestic assessments grew 9%, while worldwide GDV grew 13%. This 4 ppt GAAP is primarily due to the impact of local currency somewhat offset by pricing. Cross-border volume fees grew 11%. While cross-border volume growth 16%. Of the site ppt crop, the majority is just a higher mix of intra-Europe activity, some local currency impact, as well as lower inbound U.S. cross-border volume.
Transaction processing fees grew 16%, primarily driven by the 12% growth in process transaction and some pricing. Finally, other revenues grew 15%, driven primarily this quarter by our safety and security products and the APT acquisition.
Moving on to Page 7. Here, you can see the total operating expenses after excluding the special item increased 1% in the quarter or 5% on an FX adjusted basis. Of this, M&A activities contributed almost 4 ppt to total FX-adjusted expense growth. And you can see the impact acquisition had to the individual expense categories in the lower box here on the chart. After excluding the special item, the growth in G&A of 3% or 6% on an FX-adjusted basis is mostly due to the impact of acquisitions. And finally, most of the increase in D&A continues to be also related to acquisitions.
Turning to Slide 8. Let's discuss what we have seen in October through the 21st. Our business drivers are similar or just a bit lower compared to the third quarter. So the numbers through October 21 are as follows. Starting with processed volume, we saw global growth of 12%, which is unchanged from the third quarter. In the U.S, our processed volume grew 7%, that is also unchanged from what we saw in the last quarter. Processed volume outside the U.S. grew 17%. That's about 1 ppt lower than the third quarter with similar growth in Europe and slightly lower growth in the other regions.
Globally, processed transaction growth was 11%, down 1 ppt from what we saw in the third quarter, with double-digit growth in all regions except the U.S, which grew in the low single-digits. This slower U.S. growth was driven by routing decisions of PIN debit transactions. With respect to cross-border. Our volume grew 14% globally, 2 ppt lower than our third quarter growth with slower growth in all regions except the U.S. Our APMEA region saw the largest slowdown driven by the timing of holidays in the Middle East versus last year.
Moving on, our volume and transactions metrics, as we can see, show that our underlying business remains strong. When looking at our full year 2015 outlook, it's mostly unchanged from my comments last month at our Investor Day. I'll just quickly call out a few items that have changed very slightly or need some clarification.
First, similar to what we saw in Q3, we now expect a slightly higher local currency headwinds of about 3 ppt in Q4, which primarily impacts net revenue. And when you combine you this with the impact from FX translation, the total expected impact of currency on our results continues to be a 8 to 10 ppt headwind for fiscal year 2015, depending whether we're talking about revenue or net income.
Turning to rebates and incentives. We continue to expect the full year 2015 growth rate to be similar to the growth rate we saw in Q1. However, the individual quarterly impact has changed slightly due to the timing of some deals shifting from Q3 into Q4. And when looking at expenses, we haven't changed our expectations for total operating expense growth, but we have had several questions on this topic as some of you work on your models. So when I spoke previously about expecting mid single-digit growth for full year 2015 on a "as supported basis." So that excludes any of the special items taken this year, but it does not exclude the impact of last year's Q4 severance charge has that was not a special item.
Finally, let me just made a quick comment on our 2016 to 2018 performance objectives that we announced at Investor Day last month. Based on some conversation that we've had, I'd like to clarify a couple of points around our look at our long-term performance objective to help you with your modeling.
So first, our objective to present a compound growth rate over a 3-year period. So as you know, actual performance could be above or below our stated 3-year objective at any given year. Factors that could impact any individual year include things like the economic environment, the impact of local FX that we don't adjust for or market share changes. In fact, we expect that we will likely see 2015 coming lower than the range of our 2013 to '15 objectives based on the first 2 factors I just mentioned even though we expect to meet our 3-year objective.
Second, I said at Investor Day that our 2016 tax rate will be about 29%, higher than our expected 2015 rate since we don't expect the discrete and one-time items that already have or could occur this year will repeat in 2016. Remember that our practice has been to adjust for one-time tax items in the base year from which the 3-year EPS CAGR is calculated. We will be providing you with a pro forma fiscal year 2015 EPS figure on our year-end earnings call based on a normalized 2015 tax rate. And as you begin to model out future year's performance, you need to factor something about this into your thinking until we have the final numbers to provide you at the end of January.
Now let me turn the call back to Barbara to begin the Q&A session. Barbara?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ajay, I was wondering if you could, just given the volatility of the economics around the world and a little bit of a dip in cross-border this quarter, although last year, had a similar sort of holiday seasonal dip. Is there any concern structurally about
componenttext: Ajay, I was wondering if you could, just given the volatility of the economics around the world and a little bit of a dip in cross-border this quarter, although last year, had a similar sort of holiday seasonal dip. Is there any concern structurally about cross-border? Or do you feel like it's likely to remain on track despite what's going on?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's more likely to remain on track despite what's going on. Just the reality is when the dollar is strong, you're going to get slower influent of the U.S. tourism. We have seen more Americans travel overseas over the last 6, 7 months, and th
componenttext: Yes, I think it's more likely to remain on track despite what's going on. Just the reality is when the dollar is strong, you're going to get slower influent of the U.S. tourism. We have seen more Americans travel overseas over the last 6, 7 months, and that does show up in some of our results in terms of acquired volume in countries overseas. The European seem continue to be traveling, but they travel more in Europe than outside than 2, 3 years ago. There's kind of these trends moving around. Fewer Chinese are traveling overseas, no doubt. And that's all part of the way the Chinese economy is. You see in's and outside don't think I can give you a clear production of where that could go. But I don't see any structural change, if that was your question was.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. [indiscernible] what do you think from a network perspective? And are you just waiting to see if any of your issuing banks decide pursue some type of kind of chased net type approach? Or do you feel like that's something you might pu
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. [indiscernible] what do you think from a network perspective? And are you just waiting to see if any of your issuing banks decide pursue some type of kind of chased net type approach? Or do you feel like that's something you might push the issuers to kind of maintain market share?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you got to remember that shares net is a very unique piece for Chase, which has a certain size of an acquiring business and a issuing business, and they tend to be similar sized in terms of market share and they own the acquiring business. And there
componenttext: Well, you got to remember that shares net is a very unique piece for Chase, which has a certain size of an acquiring business and a issuing business, and they tend to be similar sized in terms of market share and they own the acquiring business. And there are a lot of other banks around the world that do that directly. It doesn't mean that it is in potential to discuss with everyone of them. A lot of them interested when the first set of announcements came out, that is lower interest over time because people are trying to figure out what the benefits and the pluses and minuses and the pluses takes out on a. I don't think there's clarity yet. But the conversations continue in all kinds of countries. We've done something similar in a couple of countries overseas, but it just depends on the construct of a country.

componenttext: So USA is a longtime client of ours, and we actually think they are very good client. So it's pretty fast for us that if I'm the company we feel bad about the fact that we no longer have them as our over the course of next year. We still are doing work with them on services, on rewards and debit processing. And in that form, we're doing contact with them. The factors that we tried our best to pursue that business. But at a point, we lost touch, and that's just the way it is.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: No, no, what I was suggesting, you are not making an adjustment for the 2014 numbers. You might remember that in Q4, we took a severance charge of around $87 million last year. That was not a special item, so do not pull that out. You need to put that and give that into the basic expenses when you do the calculation of mid single-digit growth.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Tien-tsin Huang of JPMorgan.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a follow-up on USA. Just trying to think about it. I'm just trying to understand how you balance pricing discipline, which I think you mentioned in a few articles with the indirect cost and losing on recent scale given that it such a
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a follow-up on USA. Just trying to think about it. I'm just trying to understand how you balance pricing discipline, which I think you mentioned in a few articles with the indirect cost and losing on recent scale given that it such a big, big line. I know Visa is obviously, bigger and are going to get bigger with us when and cost call. Some just return a sense if that makes sense.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Tien-tsin. Actually, in terms economy, the scale doesn't have material enough dimension to move when you got tens of billions of transactions in so many clients. We -- look, we win business and we lose some business. It's the nature of our busi
componenttext: Yes, sure, Tien-tsin. Actually, in terms economy, the scale doesn't have material enough dimension to move when you got tens of billions of transactions in so many clients. We -- look, we win business and we lose some business. It's the nature of our business. When it's very large, it could make an impact to the way we think. But remember that Chase was a very large movement away and we still navigated our way through the years, delivering on our 3-year commitment. USAA is no other side of Chase, you all know that. So well factored into our thinking. But I thought scale was a pricing issue. At the end of the day, it's not just pricing. There's a lot of factors that go into winning and losing does. Pricing is one of them. Pricing is always a first conversation in a B2B business. And we kind of said at some point in time that there are some business we could win, and we have to get away from it to stay. Because as I said in some to had for 30 years, but we're going to still keep doing business with them in portions of processing with and the like.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just wanted to ask a little bit about the commercial business. We've been doing a lot more work on that. Seems like you guys have a really good position in a virtual card space, specifically within commercial. Can you talk about some of the growth rate
componenttext: So just wanted to ask a little bit about the commercial business. We've been doing a lot more work on that. Seems like you guys have a really good position in a virtual card space, specifically within commercial. Can you talk about some of the growth rates you're seeing here? Maybe which reticles we're dropping some of the strengths in virtual specifically and the commercial business more broadly. And then just a quick one for Martina on buyback authorization. Any reason we haven't seen a refresh on that now that you're down closer to $1 billion?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Martina, do you want to cover the buyback first?
componenttext: Martina, do you want to cover the buyback first?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I mean, Jason, we have a particular cadence in terms of establish, although not many years in terms of the buyback authorizations. And I don't think we have a pattern reauthorization when we were still over the $1 billion mark. So that's a decision
componenttext: Look, I mean, Jason, we have a particular cadence in terms of establish, although not many years in terms of the buyback authorizations. And I don't think we have a pattern reauthorization when we were still over the $1 billion mark. So that's a decision and that will be taken at some point in time. But at this point in time, we still have plenty of opportunity in room left on the current program.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just going back to the commercial courts. I think it continue to be an area of growth. We just spent a little time, as you remember, on the Investor Day topic. We recently signed a deal Barclays in the U.K. We continued to see sort of strong adoption
componenttext: And just going back to the commercial courts. I think it continue to be an area of growth. We just spent a little time, as you remember, on the Investor Day topic. We recently signed a deal Barclays in the U.K. We continued to see sort of strong adoption of our products smart data, which is our reporting and reconciliation tool, as well as in control, which is the virtual card question you were getting at. What I'm also see some increasing interest beyond the typical bankcard issuers. And you see technology providers who kind of embed commercial payment solutions either into their software or their platforms. And as well as some payment aggregators in verticals insurance and health care. All in all, there's global business remains robust. We are looking at low double-digit volume growth over the past several quarters. And there's no doubt that virtual cards are a key part of that growth area. As you know, in control, when we bought all this time years ago, in control came I be production or other virtual card space. And it's embedded into what we are doing in the commercial space.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Just wanted to go back to some your comments of yours, Ajay, the Chase net deal and how -- you guys have a similar product. And it was just wondering, specific to the United States, I mean, has there been a steady stream discussions with some of the banks that are able to do it? And what's their interest level?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: They've been discussions over time. I wouldn't call it a steady stream. It's kind of -- some banks pursue it for it period of time. Others come in and out of their discussion. I'd say every once in a while, there are conversations on it with different ban
componenttext: They've been discussions over time. I wouldn't call it a steady stream. It's kind of -- some banks pursue it for it period of time. Others come in and out of their discussion. I'd say every once in a while, there are conversations on it with different banks here. Just -- it's not -- there's nobody also got that same position. But yes, it's something that we're doing overseas that said, in some countries and there's always the opportunity to do it in the U.S. as well if the stars and the moon align.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

That Payment Security Task Force that some assumptions and health cards would get replaced and how terminals get upgraded. And while the end of 2017 is all the cards is going to replace it's actually not a renewal until that. It's pretty high already at 60-odd percent by the end of this year. And I think by the end of next year, mostly done with a few left in 2017. It's a similar trend for terminals. But remember, smaller margins will take longer because they've got to work through the ISO network. And there's a whole game out there to replay. But it's over the next couple years, it should be quite well embedded.

componenttext: Two-part question one is [indiscernible] in the U.S. for MasterPass in the online space and trying to compete with PayPal and all of their competitors targeting. Adjusts we have seen a lot of traction. You've got some big-name merchants. But I just don't understand exactly why merchants aren't eager to adopt something that would help consumers check out. And the second part of the question is, when it comes to MCX, just any current thoughts on the competitive threat there. Do you expect it to being included in MC ask at some point? Do you expect it also include your 2-stage wallet fee as part of the arrangement with MCX?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the first part, the part of that adoption. Building acceptance is relatively long marathon. And we've kind of all forget and that because we've built in the physical space for a paired of time with cards, and that cards become more and more ubiquitous.
componenttext: So the first part, the part of that adoption. Building acceptance is relatively long marathon. And we've kind of all forget and that because we've built in the physical space for a paired of time with cards, and that cards become more and more ubiquitous. Acceptance tends to a lot faster. But we know where it's like to build acceptance in emerging markets, for example, where the infrastructure may not be as strong or where the number of cards in people's pockets may be lower. So it's old bit of a chicken and egg. Merchants begin to accept electronic payments when there's enough for consumers of that. Consumers also tend to pick up electronic payments when there's enough acceptance for them. And this symbiotic thing takes a little time to pick up a role amount inside. A bit like a snowball rolling downhill. Think of it that way. And it's pretty much of the same way. Paintball given a very good job of building their acceptance. We've only started a little while ago. And I think, as you make progress on building acceptance on this, you'll get chunks of merchants at sometimes. Another times, it's a one-by-one kind of thing. One of the things we have learned is that it's really important to build acceptance for this on the -- in the day-to-day merchant usage category because that will encourage consumers to use their MasterPass wallet or their bank wallet more often. And the moment you do that, the merchant gets reinforced that this is a good thing to connect up with, and that's what we're trying to do. So you'll see us make a lot of effort on this and you'll see the whole industry making efforts over the last year or so. You'll see us all doing this for the next couple of years. And don't judge MasterPass or the digital payment system as a whole by Sprint. Judge our sound. Otherwise, by that logic, none of the current global payment on digital payment systems have reached a scale. Don't do that because I think it's a cumulative effect over a period of time. That's the way I look at it.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay and on MCX?
componenttext: Okay and on MCX?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think MCX is interesting. I would change my opinion about my previous view. I haven't yet seen anything you rollout from them. I consider them to all be very large and useful merchants. We're doing many relationships. So we're working with all of the
componenttext: So I think MCX is interesting. I would change my opinion about my previous view. I haven't yet seen anything you rollout from them. I consider them to all be very large and useful merchants. We're doing many relationships. So we're working with all of them. And we'll see, we'll see when they launch something and what the experience is. Finally, in digital payment, mobile based payments, a lot of this is going to about the consumer experience. Because if it's going to be clunky, then what problem are you trying to solve with that technology that the consumer is feeling today with a card. It's not -- you not solving for that convenience and for the ease-of-use. And so it's all about the consumer experience in addition to all the other elements of the ecosystem. So I'm missing. I'm working with them. We meet them. We talked to them. We'll see. The stage wallet fee is very much something that's a principal policy in our company. We believe that if you were take funding sources from different sources and not provide clarity to the merchant, the consumer and the issuing institution at the end of what funding source are used to what purchase, it kind of mixing up a lot of things. You're mixing up a lot of issues in the market place, including how you provide customer service and the value of different payment systems, both for the merchant and the consumer and the issuing banks. So this kind of a policy around that, and we're sticking to that policy.

componenttext: So first of all, on the first question, Smitti, look, the PIN U.S. business is a top business, right? it's a very competitive business. We've been explaining to you that we are extremely price conscious about that and that every month, we are making sure that we get the right kind of transactions and the right number of transactions coming in into our network. But things move, right? Competitively, they move. Some cards get added other PIN option. So that moves them in terms of what you see on other networks. And so every month, we are basically working as often. This month -- this what you saw the bit of a step down. You also saw that in October. I think over the next 3, 4 months, we'll be regaining some of that as we're working through that competitive environment.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: In the other revenue line, you called out, Martina, safety and security solutions. And I'm wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on that in terms of being able to monetize or commercialize tokenization and encryption offerings. Or what specifically is in there? And can that be a driver of revenue growth that the margin looking out over the next several years?

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, safety and security, you can't just look at this in terms of what we're doing on the tokenization or in the MDSPs. Safety and security is a much broader kind of umbrella, and we actually pulled all of our safety and security product offering togethe
componenttext: Look, safety and security, you can't just look at this in terms of what we're doing on the tokenization or in the MDSPs. Safety and security is a much broader kind of umbrella, and we actually pulled all of our safety and security product offering together a couple of years ago under one leadership. And what is really what we're after is one other item products and services can we offer that keeps the consumer safe, that keeps the merchant safe and that keeps the financial institutions and the space. So you have a number of players in the industry that are having the same kind of thinking in terms of keeping everybody safe. We have at the time of unbelievably interesting products that we have built on the very good base over last couple of years. I'll give you one example. So for instance, the product that we call, SafetyNet, and some of you saw that of course, at our Investor Day, right? On safety net, we basically have in the network algorithms that allow us to detect if particular cards or portfolios have been penetrated in such a way that there are red flags coming out, and we have to make sure that the financial institutions or the related party actually knows how to deal with that. And we do that with a nanoseconds, right? Those kind of products, which have been rolled out worldwide, SafetyNet has been now rolled out worldwide, we can absolutely charge for. And that is some of the things that the charges that people will agree to, they have to agree to if they want to utilize these products. And those are the kind of revenues that you see coming in here.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So your second part of your question, which is about tokenization and all that mixed up inside that. And the safety security business to me is about prevention, detection and finally, enhancing the experience of the consumer and the merchant and the issui
componenttext: So your second part of your question, which is about tokenization and all that mixed up inside that. And the safety security business to me is about prevention, detection and finally, enhancing the experience of the consumer and the merchant and the issuing institution. And we're actually building a strategic thought process in it over the last couple of years, not just selling product. And you're seeing the result of some of that beginning to show up in our revenue lines. I'm quite hopeful that safety and security will be a good way for us to grow. We had a natural provider of some of these thinking for those people in the ecosystem. And it's necessarily a part of what we do for the consumer invest -- highly test solutions to -- we've got authorization IQ solutions for merchants to issuing solutions, to using data, to tall that. I mean -- but new technology stuff coming in where the tokenization comes. But also, self e-pay and biometrics and heat beat monitor and we launched that with the TD Bank in Canada. This is the whole series of things in the space. I don't think tokenization itself should be counted as a revenue stream per se. Tokenization is probably like payment stakes. We don't charge for EMV, a chip manufacturer may be charging some money to provide a chip. We don't charge for them extra. That's [indiscernible] and digital. So that's what I'm trying to do with tokenization, trying to make it safer, more secure, EMV tight security in digital for the future payments that are going to go digital. But there's a lot of other places in safety and security where you can make good money and good revenue for providing a service that people can opt into and use. That's what we're trying to do.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of questions back and forth in Visa in Visa Europe. I think we've answered them a few times, but I'll go over a couple of thoughts for you. And the first one is whatever did you have this, that is going to be some period of time during which
componenttext: There's a lot of questions back and forth in Visa in Visa Europe. I think we've answered them a few times, but I'll go over a couple of thoughts for you. And the first one is whatever did you have this, that is going to be some period of time during which the integration of these businesses from a technology, culture, operation point of view, will take some energy, effort and dedication. And we've seen that in our prior transactions in MasterCard even before I join not just with the IPO, but even before the IPO with the purchase or Europay. And there is a fair amount of work and challenge that needs to go into it. That will happen. When that's done over a period of some years, there's no doubt that one of the things that we do use today to go talk to global banks or global merchants had recognizing that aren't too many global banks left, but they're our global merchants. The ability to offer a unified proposition, that's one which was unique to us in some ways, will no longer be unique to us. And that will change the competitive landscape in some ways when this integration is completely done. In the meanwhile, there build lots of moving around and that's all opportunities. And you're just [indiscernible] some of those that aren't maybe its pricing. Maybe its deal terms and all those could be interesting ideas for us to explore. They're going to try. And as you can imagine, we've got people who have been thinking about this for a while. I'm pretty certain that as Visa is going through that thinking, they've got people thinking about how to prevent that from happening. And that's of the usual game in B2B. It will be a lot of fun.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping you can help me figure out some of these recent co-brand deals where interchange has been presumably guaranteed at a much lower rate. And these warehouse deals, like Costco and Sam's Club, where you might see a large influx of small busi
componenttext: I was just hoping you can help me figure out some of these recent co-brand deals where interchange has been presumably guaranteed at a much lower rate. And these warehouse deals, like Costco and Sam's Club, where you might see a large influx of small business spend because of the nature of those businesses, how you reconcile for the bank where you -- where interchange has been cut down to 40 basis points, but they might have small business card with 150 basis point cash back and no receivables balances that roll over. I mean, I would imagine there's got to be, over the coming years, some breaking point in this paradigm where something has to change.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, I mean, this a very specific certain aspect of our business, right? And I don't know all those numbers you just talked about because some of them are unfamiliar to me and probably know somebody else that may have done deals of that type. But I don'
componenttext: Craig, I mean, this a very specific certain aspect of our business, right? And I don't know all those numbers you just talked about because some of them are unfamiliar to me and probably know somebody else that may have done deals of that type. But I don't know about those. I do know that at the end of the day, interchange, which was, once upon a time, many years ago, just basically announcement that went out with some kind of level built in for category of spend. Over the years, as you've noticed in many parts of the world, interchange discussions aren't that inflexible. And they do have discussions of merchants. It's not just in the United States. It happens outside as well. If you, for example, were have to look on interchange on a high-value payment for electricity bills or for utilities, it's very different from the interchange in a different kind of store. And so, in a way, in fact, the saving of merchant discount rates and interchange were based on these kinds of conversations between merchants and acquirers, and networks and issuing banks, is part of what the industry is dealing with. And I don't know that that's such a bad thing. I think, in fact, if anything, it makes some of the claims of that being only a one side of perspective of just pricing being one way. A little less sound with. A little less probable because of these infections are being discussed among than at some point in time, that it means relatively open negotiation [indiscernible] and some issuers and some networks and so on. I don't know that all of that is a bad thing. And I think the fact that revolver in some card and some card may go to one merchant, which may have a different interchange flow makes you think that the only revenue stream for a card is some interchange. And I think that's inappropriate, too. There are total revenue streams into a card, multiple revenue streams into an issuer, multiple revenue streams that get used to providing a series of consumer benefit across tens of millions of merchants, not one. So I wouldn't try and equate one merchant with one card. That's not how this business is built.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: And if I can follow up quickly. We've seen Congress look at why merchants are not getting any break for putting EMV in place if it's supposedly to lower fraud gas. I mean, it would make sense to me to get that narrative back and say you put in this capability, and we will offer discount, but you have to do this for us and we'll reciprocate. I'm not just [indiscernible] many discussion.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, it still is a very small start. And we're still talking -- look, 1% of the transactions are right now on a mobile phone and in some cases, in certain markets. Well, 99% of the stuff is still happening in a certain way. Even e-commerce, in brow
componenttext: No, no, no, it still is a very small start. And we're still talking -- look, 1% of the transactions are right now on a mobile phone and in some cases, in certain markets. Well, 99% of the stuff is still happening in a certain way. Even e-commerce, in browser, base payments e-commerce, it's 6% or 7% of the ATM transactions in the U.S. So I'm very focused on making sure that we get the EMV done, that in the liability shift discussion out there, have it establish, have it be the way, in which the system is that. And I'm sure, over time, you'll be -- digital space becomes larger. Similar logical prevail bill, I don't know exactly how it will prevail, I don't know what the mid-nature will be. So not going to speculate. But one step at a time. This is just to me the liability shift. Remember, when we first announced it a couple of years ago, we were pretty much out there on our own for a while because it's new and its need to settle in. So I said, watch that space over time as it rose.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, so my senses that's over the last year or 2, a number of the larger and even some of the medium-sized and smaller issuer are clearly back on the market with an appetite for driving consumer acquisition. And I mean that in the credit-debit kind of cre
componenttext: Hey, so my senses that's over the last year or 2, a number of the larger and even some of the medium-sized and smaller issuer are clearly back on the market with an appetite for driving consumer acquisition. And I mean that in the credit-debit kind of credit space. Prepaid have been growing for a while. Commercial have been growing for all. Some banks, even during the crisis, where they are able to sustain their ability to keep acquiring. You know that they've come out of this to the right vintages. And you can see the result in their growth rates of card ownership and spend rates. Others have to hold back for a while and allow back in the market. I cannot see things happening. I don't think that card acquisition growth rates are being held back only by rates differential. It's also by their comfort around credit quality. And in fact, that's where it start from. And you can see that, that credit quality for the banks have improved. There [indiscernible] have down. Write-offs have come down. Their whole approach to being thoughtful about how to acquire consumers is very much back in the space.

componenttextpreview: APT actually is just a quarter, the second quarter now, right? So it's really no new news. So we have good traction with APT. We've actually got a number of deals that are in different stages of either being -- having been signed and getting implemented a
componenttext: APT actually is just a quarter, the second quarter now, right? So it's really no new news. So we have good traction with APT. We've actually got a number of deals that are in different stages of either being -- having been signed and getting implemented at spy because that's typically how this. It's a test and learn thing. That's what APTs are into. yield Gen2 start of the pile of the climb if its worked well, look at a bigger piece of business from that automotive into a different space. And that's pretty much what's going on. We're actually very excited about APT. It's got its huge potential for merchants. Remember, the best part about APT see that in the data that leave the market and champ it stays in the market share. What's built into the terminals of the merchant shop is different to was that the APT team develops with her intellectual property on the test and learn capabilities. So it makes merchant far more comfortable. On anonymized data can be used to make that tool even more predictable. But that data doesn't leave their shops. So that's actually pretty interesting opportunity. 5 1. 5 1 was a much smaller business when we bought it, but it's completely integrated into what we are doing and giving us a great deal of much attraction across the world. They were very focused in a few markets that it's moving to other places then you saw when Kevin standing up on the Investor Day recently, he talked about examples of what we were doing with merchants. And that's where they headed a. I'd say, watching this space. It's early days. We are beginning to see good relationships and frequent repurchasing from the merchants of things we're doing with them. It'll take us 3, 4, 5 years to make this what we want it to be, but we are very focused on it.

componenttext: And Lisa, what's good is even early days, I mean, even for 5 1, which we just have out for 1 year, [ph] for both 5 1 NAV 2, we already put some points on the Board in terms of real agreements that are driving some revenues for those businesses, and that's very gratifying to see.

componenttext: My question is probably a little far afield, but there's a lot of energy going into this topic. And I'm interested in your perspective on how law changed technologies or distributed ledger technology sweep integrated into remittance and payments generally and specifically what MasterCard's activities are in the space. Now I'm ignoring bit coin, I have no interest in that. Really just locking technologies, please.

headline: MasterCard Incorporated, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken, I think what has got potential. I've said this publicly quite a few times now in different panels and statements that I make. I think the real issue here will be will legal dispute settlement systems accept a distributed leisure is available res
componenttext:
Yes, Ken, I think what has got potential. I've said this publicly quite a few times now in different panels and statements that I make. I think the real issue here will be will legal dispute settlement systems accept a distributed leisure is available resulted in a call for it if [indiscernible] with our base before its and a receiver. Finally, the whole payment system works on 2 or 3 things. Trust that the money will get in there. Two, that it will be accurate. Three, that its is not as accurate as of the methodology to get your money back. I think that's going to have to be more of the methodology, of reaching people, which in this case, if there's a distributed chain and you don't know who they are, that's a little comp look at it. Than alternatively, a legal settlement process that you have recourse to. I think all that needs to be figure out. In addition to the basics, which is will also see acceptance for in the case of remittances and other things, will it be accepted for the right kind of level playing field by the regulators on KYC and anti-money laundering and those kinds of things. I believe that over a period of time, either the block chain, the way it is today, or some derivative of it, as we all experiment and evolve with it an engage in dialogue with it, I'm sure the level whether its remittance or payments or it's in different kinds of record-keeping or it's an asset transfer or it's a mix of all those, I don't yet know. But I think not engaging with it will be a series seller. And not of people in our MasterCard Labs -- actually if you ever wanted to them, that will be a good character to talk less the casino's more about this than I'll ever learn. And he will tell you that we've been experimenting in this space for a while. We've got patents in this space. We've got experimentations and lab designs in the space. We've got investments states. We've got investments directly in companies in that space to learn and I guess make mistakes along the way, but that's what we're doing.
Okay. So thank you all for your question. I'm going to leave you with a very short list of a few closing thoughts. And the first is I continue to think that our business are performing well. You can see that's reflected in our continuing strong volume, strong transaction growth, global economic uncertainty remains. We're seeing that in the base of growth in some regions, in some aspects, as the first question I got about cross-border. We are pleased with the progress with all of our EMV in the U.S., continuing to build with our mountain with MasterPass, and MD-80 and tokenization in the additional payments pace, but it's early days. We remain focused on driving future growth opportunities, while managing what we're going through today and the needs of our business Citi. So thank you, so much for your content support of the company, and thank you for joining us today.
